choices.text: Previous infection even if patient has been asymptomatic
That the patient is in window period

questions.text: The presence of antibodies against SARS CoV2 in the blood likely indicates? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Previous infection even if patient has been asymptomatic

 

The presence of antibodies against SARS CoV 2 in the blood likely indicates a previous infection even if the patient has been asymptomatic.

 

1-3 weeks after symptoms onset, SARS CoV2 antibody become detectable. At this time infectiousness is decreased and some amount of immunity from future infection has developed.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Presence of acute viral load: The presence of antibodies does not indicate an acute viral load. Acute infection is usually detected through the presence of viral RNA using PCR tests, not antibodies.

 

Option C. A high risk of reinfection: The presence of antibodies suggests that the individual has some level of immunity, which generally reduces the risk of reinfection rather than increasing it.

 

Option D. That the patient is in window period: The window period refers to the time after initial infection when antibodies are not yet detectable. Therefore, the presence of antibodies indicates that the patient is beyond the window period.

 

Educational objective

 

The presence of antibodies against SARS-CoV-2 in the blood likely indicates a previous infection, which may have been asymptomatic. This serological evidence shows that the person has developed an immune response to the virus.

choices.text: Rabbit ileal loop for enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli
Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a suspected dengue patient
Injecting a hamster with splenic biopsy for diagnosis of leishmaniasis
Intradermal test on guinea pigs for toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheria

questions.text: Which of the following is a Xenodiagnostic method? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a suspected dengue patient

 

Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a suspected dengue patient is the Xeno diagnostic method among the given options.

 

Xenodiagnosis is a diagnostic method used to document the presence of infectious disease microorganisms or pathogens by exposing possibly infected tissue to a vector and then examining the vector for the presence of the microorganisms or pathogens it may have ingested.

 

Uses -

 

  1. Chagas disease diagnosis. Reduviid bugs (vector/foreign host) grown in laboratories are permitted to feed on suspicious patients (original host). The feces of the bugs are checked under a microscope for amastigote forms of the pathogen Trypanosoma cruzi after 4-5 weeks.
  2. Identification of dengue virus – viruses are inoculated into the mosquitoes . The virus can be demonstrated easily as it multiplies in different organs of the mosquito (Aedes aegypti, Aedes albopictus, and Toxorhynchites) and can be easily demonstrated.
  3. In Trichinella spirals infection, Laboratory rats are used as a T. spiralis vector by feeding them pieces of muscle biopsies from suspected patients. The infected lab rats' muscles can be seen to contain T. spiralis larvae.

 

Advantage of xenodiagnosis: helpful in cases where low pathogen count makes direct microscopic diagnosis DIFFICULT.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Rabbit ileal loop for enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli: Incorrect: This is not a xenodiagnostic method. It involves testing the virulence of enterotoxigenic E. coli by observing the fluid accumulation in ligated sections of rabbit intestine.

 

Option C. Injecting a hamster with splenic biopsy for diagnosis of leishmaniasis: Incorrect: This method involves animal inoculation rather than using a vector to diagnose an infection.

 

Option D. Intradermal test on guinea pigs for toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheria: Incorrect: This is a virulence testing method to determine the presence of toxigenic strains of Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

 

Educational Objective

 

Xenodiagnosis involves using a vector to ingest potentially infected tissue or fluids and then examining the vector for the presence of the pathogen, making it particularly useful in cases where direct detection of the pathogen is challenging due to low numbers.

questions.text: Identify the following instrument commonly used in obstetrics? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Episiotomy scissors

 

The instrument shown in the picture is an episiotomy scissors. The angulation in the scissor is designed to prevent the extension of a pelvic tear into the anal margins and to avoid obstetric anal sphincter injuries or complete perineal tears.

 

An episiotomy is not given routinely. Its use should be restricted to specific situations such as:

 

  • Macrosomia: When the baby is larger than average.
  • After coming head of breech: To facilitate the delivery of the head in a breech birth.
  • Instrumental delivery: When tools like forceps or vacuum are used to assist in delivery.
  • Shoulder dystocia: A delivery complication where the baby's shoulders get stuck.
  • Rigid perineum: Often seen in primigravida, where the perineum does not stretch easily.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mayo scissors: General-purpose surgical scissors used for cutting tissues.

 

Option B. Curved scissors: Scissors with a curved blade, used for various surgical procedures but not specifically for episiotomy.

 

Option C. Suture remover: Scissors designed specifically for removing sutures, not for performing an episiotomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Episiotomy scissors are specifically designed to perform an episiotomy, which is a surgical incision made in the perineum to facilitate childbirth and prevent severe perineal tears. Their use is restricted to specific obstetric situations to avoid unnecessary complications.

 

Ref: Page no 755 Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

choices.text: Involves degranulation of mast cells
Can occur on first exposure
Most commonly caused by NSAIDs

questions.text: True about anaphylactoid reaction are all except: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IgE mediated

 

  • Anaphylactoid reactions are defined as those reactions that produce the same clinical picture with anaphylaxis but are not IgE mediated, occur through a direct nonimmune-mediated release of mediators from mast cells and/or basophils or result from direct complement activation.
  • Unlike the classic anaphylaxis which occurs on re-exposure to the allergen, the anaphylactoid reaction can occur even on the first exposure. The most common agents that can cause an anaphylactoid reaction include NSAIDs and radiocontrast media.

 

According to World allergy organization (WAO) anaphylaxis guidance 2020

 

IgE-mediated anaphylaxis is considered the classic and most frequent mechanism. In this type, anaphylaxis is triggered by the interaction of an allergen (usually a protein) interacting with the allergen-specific IgE/high-affinity receptor (FcεRI) complex expressed on effector cells, predominantly mast cells and basophils. This initiates intracellular signaling resulting in the release of preformed and de novo synthesis of mediators.

 

Non–IgE-mediated anaphylaxis may be immunologic or non-immunologic

 

  • Non-IgE-mediated immunologic mechanisms may involve the activation of pathways such as the complement system (anaphylatoxins, C3a, and C5a), the contact and coagulation system activation or immunoglobulin G (IgG)- mediated anaphylaxis.
  • Non-immunologic mechanisms have been described for some drugs (opioids). Ethanol and physical factors, such as exercise, may be involved in triggering anaphylaxis through mechanisms which are not fully elucidated. Mast cells may be activated through receptors by certain drugs such as neuromuscular blocking agents and fluoroquinolones.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Involves degranulation of mast cells: This is true for both anaphylaxis and anaphylactoid reactions, where mast cells release histamine and other mediators, leading to the symptoms.

 

Option C. Can occur on first exposure: This is true for anaphylactoid reactions, as they do not require prior exposure or sensitization to the allergen.

 

Option D. Most commonly caused by NSAIDs: This is true. NSAIDs are a common cause of anaphylactoid reactions, which can occur without prior exposure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anaphylactoid reactions are not IgE-mediated and can occur on first exposure to the triggering substance, with NSAIDs being one of the common causes.

questions.text: Which of the following leads would show maximum R wave with the cardiac axis as +90 degrees?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lead aVF


The cardiac axis represents the direction of the mean QRS complex, which is the average direction of ventricular depolarization. In a standard ECG, the normal adult QRS axis is directed downward and to the left, usually between -30 degrees and +100 degrees.

 

With the cardiac axis at +90 degrees, the direction of ventricular depolarization aligns with the orientation of lead aVF, which is positioned precisely at +90 degrees. Since lead aVF is aligned with the cardiac axis, it would record the maximum R wave amplitude.

 

Definitions of axis deviations:

 

  • Left axis deviation – The mean axis is more negative than -30 degrees.
  • Right axis deviation – The mean axis is more positive than +90 to +100 degrees.
  • Extreme axis deviation – The axis lies between -90 and +180 degrees, representing an abnormal or extreme shift.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lead aVL:  Lead aVL is positioned at -30 degrees, and with a cardiac axis of +90 degrees, it would not show the maximum R wave.

 

Option C. Lead I:  Lead I is oriented at 0 degrees and would not be aligned with the cardiac axis at +90 degrees, so it would not show the maximum R wave.

 

Option D. Lead II:  Lead II is positioned at +60 degrees and would not show the maximum R wave when the cardiac axis is precisely at +90 degrees.

 

Educational Objective:


When the cardiac axis is at +90 degrees, lead aVF, positioned at the same angle, will display the maximum R wave amplitude due to alignment with the direction of ventricular depolarization.

questions.text: Where are the apocrine glands present among the given options? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Axilla

 

Option C Axilla:

 

  • Apocrine glands are predominantly located in the axillae, areola and groin.
  • They are sweat glands that become active at puberty and are responsible for the body odor associated with sweating because they produce a thicker, milky sweat that, once degraded by skin bacteria, generates a noticeable odor.

 

 

  • These glands are most numerous in the axillary region, which is why the axilla is the correct answer.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Palm and Soles:

 

  • The skin of palms and soles is primarily populated with eccrine sweat glands, not apocrine.
  • Eccrine glands are involved in thermoregulation and are not associated with hair follicles. They produce a watery sweat that is not typically odorous.

 

Option B. Face:

 

  • While there are some apocrine glands on the face, they are not as numerous or as active as those in the axilla.
  • The face primarily contains sebaceous glands and eccrine sweat glands.

 

Option D. Scalp:

 

  • The scalp does have apocrine glands, but they are far less concentrated and active compared to those in the axilla.
  • The scalp also contains eccrine sweat glands and is rich in sebaceous glands.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Identify the axilla as the primary location of apocrine sweat glands.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition Page no 2.8

questions.text: The flap shown in the picture is? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Serratus anterior flap

 

The given image shows a serratus anterior flap. The serratus anterior flap is a highly reliable flap which has a consistently long pedicle. Its anatomy allows coverage of complex wounds. The underlying rib can be included as a myoosseous flap to expand the versatility of this flap.

 

  • The serratus anterior flap is a reconstructive surgical technique that uses the serratus anterior muscle, which is located between the ribs and scapula.
  • This flap is often used for chest wall reconstruction and breast reconstruction procedures.
  • It provides good vascularization and can be used to cover defects in the chest and axillary regions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pectoral Myo-cutaneous Flap: The pectoral myo-cutaneous flap is a surgical technique that utilizes tissue from the pectoral muscle and overlying skin.

 

  • It is commonly used in reconstruction after resection of oral malignancies.
  • This flap can provide a good blood supply and a natural appearance.

 

Option C. TRAM Flap (Transverse Rectus Abdominis Myocutaneous Flap): The TRAM flap is a reconstructive technique that uses tissue from the lower abdominal wall, including the rectus abdominis muscle and overlying skin.

 

  • It is often employed in breast reconstruction, providing a large amount of tissue.
  • There are two types: pedicled TRAM flap (retains its blood supply through the rectus muscle) and free TRAM flap (microvascular reconstruction).

 

Option D. VRAM Flap (Vertical Rectus Abdominis Myocutaneous Flap): The VRAM flap is similar to the TRAM flap but uses tissue from the vertical orientation of the rectus abdominis muscle.

 

  • It is also used in breast reconstruction and abdominal wall reconstruction.
  • Like the TRAM flap, it can be pedicled or free, depending on the surgical technique.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Flap surgery is a type of plastic surgery that uses tissues from another part of the body to close open wounds while having its own blood supply.
  • The site from which the tissue is obtained is called the donor site, while the site where the tissue is transferred is called the recipient site. Flaps may be of soft tissue, skin, muscle, bone, fat or fascia.

questions.text: A middle-aged female patient with a history of cholelithiasis, presented with vomiting and abdominal pain. The abdominal radiograph showed Rigler's triad. Which of these is not a component of Rigler's triad? (AIIMS 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Large bowel obstruction

 

Rigler's triad is a radiologic finding associated with gallstone ileus, consisting of three specific signs: pneumobilia (air within the biliary tree), small bowel obstruction, and an ectopic calcified gallstone, typically found in the right iliac fossa. These findings are indicative of a gallstone that has passed into the intestinal tract via a biliary-enteric fistula and is causing an obstruction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumobilia: Correctly identified as a part of Rigler's triad, indicating the presence of air within the biliary system due to a fistula between the biliary tree and the gastrointestinal tract.

 

Option B. Small Bowel Obstruction: Also a component of Rigler's triad, typically caused by the ectopic gallstone blocking the small intestine.

 

Option C. Ectopic Gall Stone: Another correct component of Rigler's triad, representing the gallstone that has migrated and is causing obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rigler triad consists of three findings seen in gallstone ileus:

 

  • Pneumobilia
  • Small Bowel Obstruction
  • Ectopic calcified gallstone, usually in the right iliac fossa

questions.text: You are a public health researcher evaluating a new screening test for early detection of a specific disease in a community. Your team successfully conducted a pilot study in a small group. Before planning a large-scale implementation, you wish to ensure that the findings from your pilot study can be applied to larger, diverse groups of individuals outside your initial sample. This ability to extrapolate the findings in the broader population, i.e. the external validity of a screening test is related to which of the following options? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Generalizability

 

  • Generalizability refers to the extent to which the findings from a study or pilot test can be applied to a broader population.
  • It is a measure of the external validity of a study.
  • Ensuring that the results of a pilot study can be extrapolated to larger, diverse groups outside the initial sample is crucial for the success of large-scale implementations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stability: Refers to the consistency of test results over time, ensuring that repeated measurements yield the same results under unchanged conditions. While important, it does not address how findings apply to different populations.

 

Option B. Objectivity: Ensures that test results are unbiased and not influenced by the person administering the test. While critical for reliable results, it does not relate to applying findings to a broader population.

 

Option D. Repeatability: Refers to the consistency of the test results when repeated under identical conditions. This is crucial for reliability but does not address the applicability of the results to different populations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

External validity of a screening test is related to generalizability.

 

Validity refers to what extent the test measures which it purports to measure (adequacy of measurement).

 

Types of Validity

questions.text: Which cell is involved in type 4/delayed type hypersensitivity? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cytotoxic T cell

 

Type IV hypersensitivity, also known as delayed-type hypersensitivity, involves T cells, particularly cytotoxic T cells (CD8+ T cells) and helper T cells (TH1 cells). When these T cells recognize antigen presented by antigen-presenting cells (like macrophages and dendritic cells), they secrete cytokines that activate macrophages and cytotoxic T cells. This leads to an inflammatory response that can cause tissue damage. The process typically takes 24-72 hours to develop, hence the term "delayed."

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Macrophage: Macrophages play a crucial role in presenting antigens and secreting cytokines, but they are not the primary cells involved in mediating the type IV hypersensitivity response.

 

Option C. Dendritic cell: Dendritic cells are important antigen-presenting cells that activate T cells, but they are not the main effector cells in type IV hypersensitivity.

 

Option D. Neutrophil: Neutrophils are involved in type III hypersensitivity reactions, where they mediate tissue damage through the release of enzymes and reactive oxygen species in response to immune complex deposition.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Cyst is opened and drainage done

questions.text: Incorrect statement about choledocal cyst is: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cyst is opened and drainage done 

 

The preferred treatment for choledochal cysts is not merely opening and draining them, but rather complete surgical removal of the cyst (cyst excision) and reconstruction of the biliary drainage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased risk of cholangiocarcinoma: The risk of cholangiocarcinoma in patients with choledochal cysts can be significantly higher than in the general population. Regular monitoring and prophylactic surgical intervention are often recommended to manage this risk.

 

Option C. Todani classification used for grading: The Todani classification is indeed used to categorize choledochal cysts based on their anatomical location and type. This classification helps guide the treatment approach and prognostic assessment, making it fundamental in the management of choledochal cysts.

 

Option D. Associated with abnormal biliopancreatic junction: Choledochal cysts are often associated with an abnormal junction of the pancreatic and biliary ducts. This anomaly can lead to pancreatic juices refluxing into the bile duct, increasing the risk of inflammation and subsequent complications like cyst formation and malignancy.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While the management of choledochal cysts involves a comprehensive approach considering the risk of malignancy, the appropriate surgical intervention usually entails the complete removal of the cyst and careful reconstruction of the biliary system, not just simple drainage.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of inherited Thrombophilia? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Factor V Leiden mutation

 

Factor V Leiden mutation is the most common inherited cause of thrombophilia. This genetic mutation makes Factor V resistant to inactivation by activated Protein C, leading to increased thrombotic risk. It is an autosomal dominant disorder and is particularly common in individuals of European descent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Protein C deficiency: Less common than Factor V Leiden; leads to increased thrombotic risk

 

Option B. Prothrombin deficiency: A rare inherited coagulation disorder that typically causes bleeding

 

Option D. Antithrombin III deficiency: Relatively rare inherited thrombophilic condition

 

Educational Objective:

 

Factor V Leiden mutation is the most common inherited cause of thrombophilia.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman visits an infertility clinic. She has a regular 28-day cycle. How should she be evaluated? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Serum progesterone on day 21

 

Explanation:

 

For a woman with a regular 28-day cycle, serum progesterone is typically measured on day 21 to assess for ovulation. Progesterone levels on day 21 of the menstrual cycle provide information about whether ovulation has occurred.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Day 21 Progesterone Measurement: In a regular 28-day cycle, day 21 corresponds to the mid-luteal phase, about 7 days after ovulation. Progesterone levels peak during this time, and values above 10 ng/mL are indicative of ovulation.
  • Purpose: This test helps to determine if the cycles are ovulatory or anovulatory.

 

Other tests for ovulation:

 

  • Basal body temperature: A biphasic temperature pattern suggests ovulation.
  • Urinary LH kits (ovulation prediction kits): Ovulation occurs the day following the peak LH surge.
  • Endometrial biopsy: This can provide histological confirmation of ovulation.
  • Ultrasonography: Follicular tracking can visualize the growth and rupture of the follicle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum progesterone on day 14: Measuring progesterone on day 14 is not useful as it corresponds to the follicular phase when progesterone levels are low and not indicative of ovulation.

 

Option C. Serum LH on day 14: While an LH surge around day 14 can indicate impending ovulation, it does not confirm that ovulation has actually occurred.

 

Option D. Serum LH on day 21: Measuring LH on day 21 is not useful for assessing ovulation, as LH levels peak around mid-cycle and are not elevated during the luteal phase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a woman with a regular 28-day menstrual cycle, measuring serum progesterone on day 21 is the appropriate method to evaluate for ovulation, with levels above 10 ng/mL indicating that ovulation has occurred.

 

Ref: Williams Textbook of gynecology 3rd edition Pg435

questions.text: Match the correct antidote with the given drug toxicity: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Benzodiazepine: Flumazenil

 

Explanation: 


Flumazenil is the specific antidote for benzodiazepine toxicity. Mechanism - it acts as a competitive antagonist at the benzodiazepine receptor site on the GABA-A receptor complex. By competitively blocking these receptors, it can rapidly reverse benzodiazepine-induced sedation and respiratory depression.

 

Other Options: 


Option A. Atropine: L-carnitine: Incorrect. Physostigmine is the antidote for atropine poisoning as it can reverse both peripheral and central anticholinergic effects. L-carnitine is used specifically for valproate-induced hepatotoxicity.

 

Option B. Barbiturate: Fomepizole: Incorrect. Barbiturates do not have a specific antidote - management involves alkalinization of urine to enhance excretion. Fomepizole is the antidote for methanol and ethylene glycol poisoning as it inhibits alcohol dehydrogenase.

 

Option C. Arsenic: Desferrioxamine: Incorrect. British Anti-Lewisite (BAL/Dimercaprol) is the antidote for arsenic poisoning. Desferrioxamine is specifically used for iron poisoning (both acute poisoning and chronic overload).

 

Educational Objective: 


Antidotes

questions.text: Please identify the retractor depicted in the image below:(INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mollison's mastoid retractor

 

  • The instrument shown in the above image is Mollison's mastoid retractor.
  • It is used in mastoidectomy to retract soft tissues after incision and elevation of flaps. It is self-retaining and hemostatic.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Joll's retractor is used in thyroid surgery. It is self-retaining retractor.

 

 

Option B. Perkins retractor is used to open small incisions with minimal damage to surrounding tissues.

 

 

Option D. Langenbeck retractor is used to hold back, edges of incisions, tissue or organs

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mollison's Mastoid retractor is specifically tailored for ear surgeries, particularly mastoidectomy, where precise and sustained retraction of soft tissues is crucial. Understanding the specific applications and features of various retractors enhances surgical efficiency and safety.

questions.text: Select the correct sequence: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Adenylyl cyclase → cAMP → PKA

 

Explanation:

 

The sequence involves the activation of a G protein-coupled receptor pathway. When a hormone binds to its receptor, the associated heterotrimeric G protein undergoes a conformational change. This change leads to the exchange of GDP for GTP on the G protein's alpha subunit, causing it to dissociate from the beta and gamma subunits.

 

The activated GTP-bound alpha subunit then interacts with adenylyl cyclase, an enzyme located on the inner membrane of the cell. Adenylyl cyclase converts ATP into cyclic AMP (cAMP). The newly formed cAMP acts as a secondary messenger that activates Protein Kinase A (PKA). PKA, in turn, phosphorylates various target proteins, leading to a cascade of cellular responses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence in the G protein-coupled receptor pathway is: Adenylyl cyclase activates the conversion of ATP to cAMP, which then activates Protein Kinase A (PKA).

questions.text: Which of the following is not classified as OCD as per ICD 11? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) PTSD

 

The International Classification of Diseases (ICD-11), like the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5), classifies a number of disorders under the umbrella of obsessive-compulsive and related disorders. However, PTSD (Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder) is not classified as an obsessive-compulsive-related disorder in ICD-11. Instead, it's classified under trauma- and stressor-related disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichotillomania: This is classified as an obsessive-compulsive-related disorder in ICD-11.

 

Option B. Body dysmorphic disorder: This too is categorized as an obsessive-compulsive-related disorder in ICD-11.

 

Option C. Hypochondriac disorder: Now termed "Illness Anxiety Disorder" in DSM-5, this is categorized as an obsessive-compulsive-related disorder in ICD-11.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Obsessive-compulsive or related disorders in ICD-11 are classified as:

 

  • Obsessive-compulsive disorder
  • Body dysmorphic disorder
  • Olfactory reference disorder
  • Hypochondriasis
  • Hoarding disorder
  • Trichotillomania
  • Excoriation disorder

 

Reference: International Classification of Diseases, 11th edition, Page No 43-47

questions.text: Identify the device shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Automated External Defibrillator

 

Explanation:

 

Automated External Defibrillator (AED):

 

  • Definition: An automated external defibrillator (AED) is a portable electronic device that automatically diagnoses the life-threatening cardiac arrhythmias of ventricular fibrillation (VF) and pulseless ventricular tachycardia, and is able to treat them through defibrillation, the application of electricity which stops the arrhythmia, allowing the heart to re-establish an effective rhythm.

 

  • Rapid Defibrillation: Rapid defibrillation is paramount in improving survival rates from sudden cardiac arrest due to ventricular fibrillation or pulseless ventricular tachycardia.

 

  • User-Friendly and Accessible: AEDs are made for laypersons and first responders, not just for medical professionals. They come with voice prompts and sometimes visual displays to guide the user through each step of the defibrillation process. This design makes it possible for people without extensive medical training to assist in a cardiac emergency.

 

  • Self-Analyzing: An AED automatically evaluates the heart rhythm of a person in cardiac arrest. If the device detects a shockable rhythm, it will instruct the user to deliver a shock; if not, it will guide the user to continue with CPR or other appropriate interventions. This ensures that shocks are only given when necessary.

 

  • Public Availability: Many public places such as airports, gyms, schools, and shopping centers have publicly accessible AEDs. Increasing the availability and visibility of AEDs in public spaces can reduce the time to defibrillation and increase survival rates from out-of-hospital cardiac arrest.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Automated External Desynchronizer: This term is incorrect and not associated with any known medical device.

 

Option C. Automated Electronic Defibrillator: This term is incorrect and not associated with any known medical device.

 

Option D. Automated External Decompressor: This term is incorrect and not associated with any known medical device.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • An Automated External Defibrillator (AED) is a crucial device for rapidly diagnosing and treating life-threatening cardiac arrhythmias through defibrillation, especially designed for use by laypersons and first responders to increase survival rates in cases of sudden cardiac arrest.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 2537

questions.text: A male baby, born to a non-consanguineous couple, presents with blisters on areas of friction. Their previous baby also experienced similar issues and unfortunately passed away at the age of 2 weeks. What is the probable diagnosis?(INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Epidermolysis bullosa

 

  • The male baby's current condition, characterized by blisters appearing in areas of friction, along with a similar history in a sibling, strongly suggests a diagnosis of a genetic condition called as epidermolysis bullosa congenita.
  • Epidermolysis bullosa is a mechano-bullous disease where blisters develop in response to mechanical trauma, often occurring in regions prone to friction such as the hands, feet, elbows, and knees.

 

 

Various types of Epidermolysis bullosa (EB) & Defects associated with them:

 

 

Other options:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The likely diagnosis in a neonate presenting with blistering at areas of friction, especially with a similar family history and early demise in a sibling, is Epidermolysis bullosa, a genetic condition causing extremely fragile skin leading to blister formation with minimal trauma.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I Chapter 71 Page no 71.4-71.16

choices.text: Cessation of smoking and do biopsy

questions.text: A patient present with oral cavity findings as seen in the image below. He is a smoker. What would you choose as your next step in the management of this patient? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cessation of smoking and do biopsy

 

  • The next step of management of this patient will be cessation of smoking and do a biopsy.
  • The patient is a chronic smoker and the following image shows leukoplakia. Leukoplakia is a premalignant condition of the oral cavity.

 

The management include: 

 

  1. Elimination of associated aetiological factors and biopsy of the lesion. Many of the lesions will disappear spontaneously if the causative agent is removed.
  2. In lesions with higher potential for malignant change, a biopsy is taken to rule out malignancy.
  3. In suspicious small lesions, surgical excision or ablation with laser or cryotherapy can be done.

 

A photographic record of the lesion is useful for long term follow up.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Give corticosteroids: There is no role for corticosteroids in the treatment of leukoplakia as they do not address the potential for malignant transformation or the underlying causes of the lesion.

 

Option C. Lifestyle Modifications: While beneficial overall, lifestyle changes alone are insufficient for managing a lesion with potential malignancy. Specific interventions like quitting smoking are required.

 

Option D. Injection vitamin B12: There is no indication that vitamin B12 injections would be effective in treating leukoplakia unless there is a specific deficiency that also needs addressing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For leukoplakia, particularly in smokers, the primary management strategy includes cessation of smoking and histological examination through biopsy. This is crucial not only to assess the current state of the lesion but also to guide further therapeutic decisions which may include surgical excision, laser ablation, or cryotherapy depending on the biopsy results. Regular monitoring and photographic documentation of the lesion are also important for long-term follow-up.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 253

choices.text: Virus shedding is present before symptoms begins
5-12 years is a high-risk group

questions.text: Which of the following is false about influenza? (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 5-12 years is a high-risk group

 

People at greater risk of severe disease or complications when infected are:

 

  1. pregnant women
  2. Children under 59 months
  3. Elderly
  4. Individuals with chronic medical conditions (such as chronic cardiac, pulmonary, renal, metabolic, neurodevelopmental, liver or hematologic diseases)
  5. Individuals with immunosuppressive conditions (such as HIV/AIDS, receiving chemotherapy or steroids, or malignancy).
  6. Health care workers are at high risk acquiring influenza virus infection due to increased exposure to the patients and risk further spread particularly to vulnerable individuals.

 

Mode of transmission – droplet infection

 

Incubation period – 1 to 4 days

 

Contagious period - About one day before developing any symptoms and up to seven days after the symptoms resolve.

 

Birds, especially aquatic birds act as reservoirs of influenza viruses. Avian influenza or bird flu refers to the disease caused by infection with avian (bird) influenza (flu) Type A viruses.

 

The secondary attack rate (SAR), defined as the probability that an infection occurs among susceptible people within a specific group (i.e., household or close contacts), can provide an indication of how social interactions relate to transmission risk. It is 5- 15% for influenza.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Virus shedding is present before symptoms begin: This is true. Influenza can be contagious before symptoms appear, which contributes to its rapid spread.

 

Option C. Aquatic birds act as a reservoir: This is true. Birds, especially aquatic birds, act as reservoirs of influenza viruses. Avian influenza, or bird flu, refers to the disease caused by infection with avian (bird) influenza (flu) Type A viruses.

 

Option D. Secondary attack rate is 5-15%: This is true. The secondary attack rate (SAR) for influenza, defined as the probability that an infection occurs among susceptible people within a specific group (e.g., household or close contacts), is typically between 5-15%.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Children under 5 years, pregnant women, the elderly, individuals with chronic medical conditions or immunosuppressive conditions, and health care workers are at greater risk of severe disease or complications from influenza. The 5-12 years age group is not specifically categorized as high-risk for severe disease from influenza.

choices.text: Pleural thickening is typical of COVID-19
Lobar consolidation is typical of COVID-19

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding CORDS? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CORADS-5 is typical of COVID-19

 

Explanation:

 

CORADS-COVID-19 Reporting and Data System

 

CO-RADS is a categorical assessment scale used to evaluate pulmonary involvement of COVID-19 on chest CT scans. Each category reflects the level of suspicion of COVID-19.  

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CO-RADS-0: This category indicates that the CT examination is insufficient for assessment, not that the lungs are normal, which is a common misunderstanding.

 

Option C. Pleural thickening: While pleural thickening can occur in COVID-19, it is not typical or diagnostic of the disease. COVID-19 primarily affects the parenchyma of the lungs rather than the pleura.

 

Option D. Lobar consolidation: Though lobar consolidation may be present in severe cases of COVID-19, it is not typical of the disease, as COVID-19 more frequently presents with peripheral ground-glass opacities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

COVID-19 Reporting and Data System (CO-RADS) is a categorical assessment for pulmonary involvement of COVID-19 on chest CT.

choices.text: Continuous air bubbles coming out of the underwater drain
Oscillation of water column in the tube

questions.text: Proper functioning of an ICD tube is checked by: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Oscillation of water column in the tube

 

Functioning of the ICD tube can be confirmed by seeing the column of water in the chest tube oscillate up and down during respiration.

 

The oscillation or fluctuation of the water column in the water seal chamber of an ICD tube is a key indicator of proper functioning. This movement indicates that there is a patent (open) airway between the pleural space and the water seal, allowing air and fluid to exit the pleural cavity and preventing air from re-entering during inhalation. It's a visual confirmation that the ICD is effectively draining the pleural space.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Continuous air bubbles coming out of the underwater drain: While air bubbles can sometimes be seen in the water seal chamber of an ICD system, their presence does not necessarily indicate proper functioning.

 

Option C. Chest X-ray: While a chest X-ray can provide valuable information about the position and placement of the ICD tube, it is not typically used as the primary method for checking its ongoing functioning. X-rays are often performed initially after tube insertion to confirm placement.

 

Option D. Auscultation: Auscultation can help assess lung sounds and detect any abnormalities, but it may not be the most direct method for checking the functioning of an ICD tube.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

An intercostal drainage (ICD) tube is a thin, plastic tube that's inserted into the pleural space. The pleural space is the area between the chest wall and the lungs. 

 

The ICD tube is used to drain abnormal collections in the pleural cavity. It helps remove: Air (pneumothorax), Blood (hemothorax), Fluid (pleural effusion or hydrothorax, Chyle (chylothorax, Purulence (empyema. 

 

The ICD tube creates negative pressure in the chest cavity, which allows the lung to re-expand.

questions.text: Which of the following supplement is required more for a lactating woman than the pregnant female? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Answer: A. Vitamin A


During lactation, the mother's body requires additional nutrients to support breast milk production, which provides all necessary nutrients for the growing infant. Some nutrient needs increase more during lactation than pregnancy.

 

Comparison of Nutritional Requirements:

 

Vitamin A:

Needed for:

  • Infant vision development
  • Immune function
  • Epithelial integrity

Significantly increased loss through breast milk

Hence, greater requirement in lactation than pregnancy

 

Others options:


B12, Calcium, and Thiamine requirements increase only slightly or remain the same.

Vitamin A shows the most significant increase.

 

Educational Objective: 

Vitamin A is required more for a lactating woman than a pregnant female. This increased need ensures that there is enough vitamin A in breast milk to support the baby's growth and development, particularly for their immune system and vision.

questions.text: A patient has complained of fever with chills. A throat examination reveals swollen glands and a thick, whitish membrane over his tonsils. Albert staining is to be done. What are the constituents of Albert's stain? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Toluidine and malachite green

 

Albert stain is used to identify metachromatic granules in bacteria, such as those seen in Corynebacterium diphtheriae. The staining technique involves two solutions: Albert stain 1 and Albert stain 2. Albert stain 1 contains Toluidine blue and Malachite green, which are basic dyes with a high affinity for acidic tissue components like cytoplasm. Toluidine blue stains the granules blue, while Malachite green provides a green background. This differential staining helps in visualizing the metachromatic granules distinctly.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carbol fuschin and methylene blue: This combination is incorrect as Carbol fuschin is used in Ziehl-Neelsen staining for acid-fast bacteria, and methylene blue is a counterstain in that procedure.

 

Option B. Carbol fuschin and malachite green: This combination is incorrect because Carbol fuschin is not used in Albert staining; it is used in acid-fast staining procedures.

 

Option D. Toluidine and methylene blue: This combination is incorrect for Albert staining. Methylene blue is a basic dye used in various other staining techniques, but not in Albert stain.

 

Educational Objective:


Albert stain contains Toluidine blue and Malachite green, used to identify metachromatic granules in bacteria like Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

questions.text: At the Urban Primary Health Centre (U-PHC), you are in charge of managing hypertension clinic services. You have 50 patients transferred from another healthcare unit for hypertension management; 40 of these patients are prescribed amlodipine (5mg, daily) and 10 are on lisinopril (10mg, daily) due to contraindications with amlodipine. Considering the need for continuous treatment and potential increases in patient numbers, calculate the number of tablets needed for the next month and determine the appropriate reorder factor. [INICET MAY 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 3000, rf=2

 

Calculation -  

 

Requirement of Amlodipine

 

40 patients x 1 Tablet per day x 30 Days = 1200 Tablets

 

Requirement of Lisinopril

 

10 patients x 1 Tablet per day x 30 Days = 300 Tablets

 

Reorder factor (Rf) for drugs supplied every:

 

  • 1 Month - 2
  • 3 Months - 6
  • 6 Months – 12

 

For the given question,

 

Total of 1500 tablets are required and reorder factor is 2

 

Hence, Total tablets required = (1200 + 300) x 2 = 3000 Tablets

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Reorder Factor (rf): A reorder factor of 2 is commonly used for monthly resupply scenarios to account for unexpected increases in patient count or dosage adjustments, ensuring no interruption in patient care.

questions.text: Which anticoagulant is used for electrolyte estimation? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lithium Heparin

 

  • Lithium Heparin is preferred for electrolyte testing because it does not interfere with the measurement of most electrolytes, such as sodium, potassium, and chloride. It is also the best anticoagulant for tests that require accurate pH, blood gases, electrolytes, and ionized calcium levels.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. EDTA: While EDTA is widely used for hematological examinations, it is not suitable for electrolyte estimation because it can chelate calcium and interfere with other ion measurements.

 

Option B. Citrate: Sodium citrate is primarily used for coagulation studies (e.g., PT, PTT) because it binds calcium ions to prevent clotting, but it is not ideal for electrolyte estimation.

 

Option C. Sodium Fluoride: Sodium fluoride is used primarily for glucose and lactate testing because it inhibits glycolysis, but it is not appropriate for electrolyte testing as it can interfere with the results.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A female presented with an ulcerated breast lump. Nipple retraction was seen, with some warmth and redness. On biopsy, it was diagnosed as invasive ductal carcinoma. According to AJCC 8th Ed., which of these correctly represents the stage? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) T4b

 

In the American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) 8th edition staging system, the classification of breast cancer stages is detailed based on tumor size, lymph node involvement, and the presence of metastasis.

 

The presentation of an ulcerated breast lump, nipple retraction, warmth, and redness suggests skin involvement, which is characteristic of a T4 classification. Specifically, the presence of ulceration and skin involvement corresponds to T4b. T4b is used when there is skin involvement in the form of ulceration, satellite skin nodules, or peau d’orange (skin changes resembling the texture of an orange).

 

While there is the possibility of inflammatory breast cancer due to the warmth and redness, the key feature here is ulceration, which is more indicative of T4b. Inflammatory breast cancer would correspond to a T4d classification, characterized by more extensive skin changes like diffuse erythema and edema (peau d'orange) involving more than one-third of the breast, often with underlying invasive ductal carcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stage IV with N1-N2 involvement: This is incorrect as there is no evidence of distant metastasis (M1), which is required for a Stage IV classification. The presence of regional lymph node involvement (N1-N2) alone does not justify a Stage IV classification.

 

Option C. Stage IIIB: This could be considered if the case were inflammatory breast cancer, but based on the ulceration and other features described, T4b is more appropriate unless additional evidence of inflammatory changes was present.

 

Option D. It cannot be M1: This statement is partially correct as the case does not mention any distant metastasis (M1), but it doesn’t address the primary tumor stage, which is the focus of the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ulceration of a breast lump with skin involvement typically corresponds to T4b in the AJCC 8th edition staging system for breast cancer. It is essential to differentiate between T4b and T4d (inflammatory breast cancer) based on the clinical presentation and pathological findings.

questions.text: A kinyoun positive oocyst (25 m) was isolated from an HIV patient with diarrhea. Identify the organism? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cystoisospora

 

Diarrhea in an HIV patient is suggestive of a coccidean parasitic infestation. Kinyoun stain positive oocysts in the image are identified as Cystoisospora.

 

Points in favor:

 

  • HIV patient with diarrhea
  • Oocysts are long and oval-shaped, which stain pink to red with Kinyoun staining.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cyclospora: Cyclospora oocysts are smaller (8-12 µm) and round, with variable acid-fast staining. They sporulate in soil and contain two sporocysts with two sporozoites each.

 

Option C. Cryptosporidium: Cryptosporidium oocysts are even smaller (4-6 µm) and round. They are uniformly acid-fast and contain four sporozoites. Sporulation occurs inside the host cell.

 

Option D. Microspora: Microspora are obligate intracellular parasites that do not have the same oocyst structure as coccidian parasites. They are detected by different staining methods and appear as small spores rather than larger oocysts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Comparison of coccidian parasites causing diarrhea in an immunocompromised host:

questions.text: IV anesthetic agent that causes adrenocortical suppression is: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Etomidate

 

Etomidate causes adrenocortical suppression by inhibiting the 11-beta hydroxylase enzyme in the adrenal cortex. This enzyme is responsible for steroid production in the body. When etomidate inhibits this enzyme, it reduces steroid production, which can lead to adrenocortical suppression. Due to this effect, etomidate should be avoided in critically ill or septic patients where maintaining adequate steroid levels is important for hemodynamic stability.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Propofol: Does not cause adrenocortical suppression. It acts mainly through GABA receptors and affects the central nervous system.

 

Option C. Thiopentone: A barbiturate that acts on GABA receptors but does not affect adrenal function or steroid synthesis.

 

Option D. Ketamine: An NMDA receptor antagonist that actually stimulates the sympathetic system and may increase steroid levels rather than suppress them.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Etomidate causes adrenocortical suppression by inhibiting 11-beta hydroxylase enzyme in the adrenal cortex, making it unsuitable for use in critically ill or septic patients who require normal steroid function.

choices.text: Intra-articular fracture distal end of radius
Extra-articular fracture distal end of radius

questions.text: An old lady fell in the bathroom with an outstretched hand. She was managed conservatively. Later on, she developed the deformity as shown in the figure. Most likely fracture sustained was:(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Extra-articular fracture distal end of radius

 

COLLE’S FRACTURE

 

  • Fracture of the distal end of radius at its corticocancellous junction, is commonly referred to as a Colle’s fracture.
  • It is typically the result of a FOOSH injury (Fall on outstretched hand) with wrist in extension.
  • It mostly occur in post-menopausal osteoporotic elderly women.
  • Symptoms and Signs:
    • Patients present with swelling, ecchymosis, tenderness, and painful range of motion of the distal forearm.
    • On examination, the classic “dinner fork” deformity (dorsal displacement of the distal fragment and volar angulation of the distal intact radius with radial shortening) may be identified.

 

 

 

  • Complications:
    • Early complications may include median nerve neuropathy, extensor pollicis longus tendon rupture, and compartment syndrome.
    • Late complications may include radiocarpal arthrosis, complex regional pain syndrome, cosmetic changes of the wrist, and fracture malunion or nonunion.
    • Finger stiffness is most common complication.
    • Malunion is the 2nd most common complication and it leads to dinner fork deformity.
    • Colles fracture is the commonest cause of Sudeck's dystrophy in upper limb.
       
  • Treatment:
    • Non-displaced extra-articular fractures are relatively stable and are treated non-operatively with a long-arm splint acutely to allow for swelling, then transitioned to a short-arm cast.
    • The cast is applied on opposite forces to displacement. The position of immobilization is:

 

  • Displaced fractures should undergo an attempt at closed reduction followed by immobilization in a long-arm sugar-tong splint acutely. Surgical fixation is indicated for distal radius fractures that fail to meet acceptable alignment criteria. Various methods include closed reduction percutaneous pinning, external fixation, and open reduction internal fixation (ORIF).
     
  • Technique of closed manipulation:
    • The muscles of forearm must be relaxed, either by general or regional anaesthesia. The surgeon grasps the injured hand as if he was ‘shaking hands’.

 

  • The first step is to disimpact the fragments which have often been driven together.

  • This is achieved by firm longitudinal traction to the hand against the counter-traction by an assistant who grasps the arm above the flexed elbow.

  • The surgeon now presses the distal fragment into palmar flexion and ulnar deviation using the thumb of his other hand.

  • As this is done, the patient’s hand is drawn into pronation, palmar flexion and ulnar deviation.

A plaster cast is applied extending from below the elbow to the metacarpal heads, maintaining the wrist in palmar flexion and ulnar deviation.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Intra-articular fracture distal end of radius. Barton's fracture is the displaced intra-articular coronal plane fracture-subluxation of dorsal lip of the distal radius with displacement of carpus with the fragment. Intra-articular component usually signifies high-energy trauma occurring in young adults, causing shear and impacted fractures of the articular surface of the distal aspect of the radius with displacement of the fracture fragments. The fracture pattern most commonly observed in geriatric age group is extra-articular while the high-energy intra-articular type is most frequent in young adult patients. Melone's classification of intra-articular distal radius fractures:

 

 

 

Intra-articular fractures of distal end of the radius can be difficult to treat, at times, with traditional conservative method. Type I and type II Melone's fracture can be managed conservatively by closed reduction and cast immobilization. External fixation is accepted as superior to plaster immobilization in the young patients with an intra-articular comminuted fracture of the distal radius. Complex intra-articular fractures in which the articular fragments are displaced, rotated or impacted are treated with open reduction and internal fixation.

 

Option C. Scaphoid fracture. It is the most commonly fractured bone in the carpus, in adult as well as children. Most commonly in males between the ages of 15 and 30. Fullness and tenderness is felt in anatomical snuff box. In adults and adolescents, middle third (Waist) fractures (70%) is more common. Nondisplaced, Stable Fractures are treated conservatively by Scaphoid Glass Holding Cast. Displaced, Unstable Fractures are treated by Headless Screw (Herbert).

 

 

 

Scaphoid glass holding cast

 

Option D. Dislocation of wrist. Wrist dislocations can occur at the radiocarpal joint, the midcarpal joint, the distal radioulnar joint or may represent a combination of these injuries in severe trauma. Carpal instability in the form of lunate and perilunate dislocations are uncommon injuries but can be frequently missed. The majority of carpal instability is centered around the lunate, given its location in the middle of the wrist. Injuries progress from scapholunate instability to lunate dislocation. Perilunate dislocations and lunate dislocations are high-energy wrist injuries involving falls from height, motor vehicle collisions, or athletic injuries. Lunate dislocate anteriorly but the rest of the carpals remain in position. In Perilunate dislocation, the lunate remains in position and the rest of the carpals dislocate dorsally. The most common type of perilunate instability is transscaphoid perilunate fracture dislocation. Median nerve is most commonly involved nerve. The most commonly used method of closed reduction is Tavernier’s maneuver.

 

 

A) Normal; (B) Lunate dislocation; (C) Perilunate dislocation; (D) Normal

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The image shown in the question is a classic dinner fork deformity, which is a complication of Colle’s fracture.
  • Colle’s fracture is most commonly seen in post-menopausal osteoporotic females after a fall on outstretched hand.

questions.text:
Arrange the following in the sequence of auditory pathway: (INICET May 2022)

 

  1. Cochlear nucleus
  2. Spiral ganglion
  3. Superior olivary nucleus
  4. Inferior colliculus
  5. Medial geniculate body
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2 -1 - 3 - 4- 5

 

The auditory pathway begins at the peripheral sensory receptors and progresses through a series of nuclei and tracts in the central nervous system before reaching the auditory cortex. The correct sequence from the periphery to the higher centers is:

 

  • Spiral ganglion (2): Located in Rosenthal's canal within the cochlea, the spiral ganglion contains bipolar neurons that send fibers through the cochlear nerve (part of the eighth cranial nerve) to the brainstem.
  • Cochlear nucleus (1): The first central auditory nucleus where the cochlear nerve fibers terminate.
  • Superior olivary nucleus (3): Serves as a major binaural processing center in the brainstem, crucial for localizing sounds in space.
  • Inferior colliculus (4): Acts as an important relay station in the midbrain, integrating auditory input before sending it to the thalamus.
  • Medial geniculate body (5): Part of the thalamus, this structure further processes auditory information before transmitting it to the auditory cortex.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • The correct sequence of structures involved in the auditory pathway from the periphery to the center is (E COLI MA).

  1. Eighth (Vestibulocochlear) nerve

  2. Cochlear Nucleus

  3. Superior Olivary nucleus

  4. Lateral lemniscus

  5. Inferior colliculus

  6. Medial geniculate body

  7. Auditory cortex

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 15

questions.text: Size cut off for operating an abdominal aortic aneurysm is greater than? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 5.5 cm

 

(5.5) The threshold for surgical repair of an AAA is commonly set at 5.5 cm in diameter. This means that when the AAA reaches or exceeds 5.5 cm in size, surgical intervention is usually recommended to prevent the risk of rupture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

AAA refers to an enlargement or ballooning of the abdominal aorta. It can be a potentially life-threatening condition if it ruptures.

 

The size of the AAA is a crucial factor in determining the need for surgical intervention. The risk of rupture increases significantly as the size of the aneurysm grows.

 

An asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm in an otherwise fit patient is considered for repair if >55 mm in diameter (measured by ultrasonography). The annual incidence of rupture rises from 1% or less in aneurysms that are <55 mm in diameter to a significant level of nearly 25%, in those that are 70 mm in diameter.

 

As open elective surgery (transabdominal) carries a 5% mortality rate, the balance is in favor of elective operation once the maximum diameter is >55 mm.

 

6 monthly follow-up ultrasonographic surveillance is indicated for asymptomatic aneurysms <55 mm in diameter.

questions.text: A patient presented with a prolonged fever of unknown origin (PUO), raising suspicion of brucellosis. To confirm the diagnosis, various dilutions of the patient's serum sample are prepared for a standard agglutination test. The outcome is as follows: No agglutination is observed at serum dilutions of 1:20 and 1:40, while positive agglutination occurs at dilutions of 1:80 and 1:160. What factor is accountable for the lack of agglutination in the initial two dilutions? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Antibody excess

 

  • Marrack proposed the lattice hypothesis → Multivalent antigens combine with Bivalent antibodies
  • Lattice is formed only when antigen and antibodies are in proportion.
  • If antigen or antibodies ,any of them is in excess - there is no lattice formation
  • The absence of a positive test result in the initial two tubes can be attributed to the prozone phenomenon.
  • In this scenario, there is an excess of antibodies in comparison to antigens, which results in a lack of robust or noticeable precipitation.

 

Zone phenomenon:

 

  1. Prozone = Ab excess = Absent
  2. Zone of equivalence = Proper proportion = Peak
  3. Post zone = Ag excess = Absent

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Incorrect antigen: If the antigen were incorrect, there would be no agglutination at any dilution.

 

Option B. Incorrect antibody: If the antibody were incorrect, there would be no agglutination at any dilution.

 

Option D. Antigen excess: Antigen excess would cause a postzone phenomenon, not observed here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The prozone phenomenon, where antibody excess prevents agglutination, can account for the lack of agglutination in low dilution samples.

questions.text: Based on the emblem as shown below, which of the following best describes the warning it signifies? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Radiation hazard

 

INTERNATIONAL RADIATION SYMBOL (TREFOIL)

 

  • Central circle of radius R, an internal radius of 1.5R and an external radius of 5R for the blades, which are separated from each other by 60°
  • Trefoil is black in the international version
  • Commonly referred to as a Radioactivity warning sign, but it is actually a warning sign of ionizing radiation
  • Includes X-ray apparatus, medical beam cannons and particle accelerators.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cytotoxic waste: This waste includes materials that are toxic to cells, such as chemotherapy waste, but uses a different symbol.

 

Option B. Biomedical waste: This refers to waste generated from medical procedures, often marked with a biohazard symbol.

 

Option D. Biohazard: Indicates the presence of biological substances that pose a threat to human health, marked with a different symbol.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 3-day-old neonate presented with recurrent bilious vomiting. An X-ray erect abdomen is shown below. What is the next best step in managing this condition? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gastrograffin follow-through

 

The given clinical history along with the radiograph showing the triple bubble sign implies a diagnosis of jejunal atresia. A contrast study should be the next best investigation to exclude other large bowel anomalies.

 

A Gastrograffin follow-through is a radiological procedure that involves the administration of contrast material (Gastrograffin) followed by a series of X-rays to visualize the gastrointestinal tract. An alternate investigation would be CT with contrast (not given in options). In cases of recurrent bilious vomiting, it is a valuable diagnostic tool to assess for intestinal obstruction, such as malrotation or other anatomical abnormalities. It helps determine if there are any blockages or abnormalities in the intestines that may be causing the vomiting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Upper GI endoscopy: Performing an endoscopy is generally not the first-line investigation for a neonate with recurrent bilious vomiting where an obstructive GI pathology is likely.

 

Option C. USG abdomen: An ultrasound (USG) of the abdomen can provide useful information in some cases, but it may not be the most appropriate initial investigation for recurrent bilious vomiting when there is a need to evaluate the entire gastrointestinal tract.

 

Option D. Explorative laparotomy: Explorative laparotomy, which involves surgery to explore the abdominal cavity, is a more invasive option and is typically considered when other diagnostic methods have failed to provide a clear diagnosis or when there is a strong suspicion of a surgical emergency. It is not the first-line choice in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Small bowel atresia’s present with intestinal obstruction soon after birth.

 

  • Bilious vomiting is the dominant feature in jejunal atresia
  • Abdominal distension is more prominent with ileal atresia.

 

A small amount of pale meconium may be passed despite the atresia.

 

Plain abdominal radiographs show a variable number of dilated loops of bowel and fluid levels according to the level of obstruction

 

In most cases of jejunal/ileal atresia, the distal end of the dilated proximal small bowel is resected and a primary end-to-end anastomosis is performed. If the proximal bowel is extremely dilated, it may need to be tapered to the distal bowel before anastomosis.

choices.text: CT angiography to look for large vessel occlusion

questions.text: A 50-year-old man suddenly developed right-sided weakness and aphasia within 2 hours. His BP recorded was 160/110 mmHg and NCCT was clear. What is the next step in management? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Thrombolysis

 

With a BP below 185/110 mmHg, clear NCCT, and symptoms within 4.5 hours, the patient qualifies for thrombolysis, the standard treatment for acute ischemic stroke to dissolve clots and restore blood flow.

 

If the blood pressure (BP) is more than or equal to 185/110 mmHg, administer IV labetalol to lower the BP to less than 185/110 mmHg before immediately proceeding with thrombolysis. CT angiography can be performed while thrombolysis is ongoing. Start the thrombolytic agent in the CT room and simultaneously inject a bolus of contrast for the CT angiogram to check for large vessel occlusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CT angiography: CT angiography can be done simultaneously with thrombolysis but not instead of it.

 

Option B. MRI: MRI is not the immediate next step when NCCT is clear.

 

Option C. Labetalol: Labetalol is used to lower BP but not the primary treatment in this context.

 

Educational Objective:


In acute ischemic stroke with BP < 185/110 and clear NCCT, thrombolysis is the next step.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with fissured tongue and peripheral neuropathy. Investigations showed reduced glutathione reductase activity. Which vitamin deficiency is the likely cause of this? (AIIMS NOVEMBER 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin B2

 

Natural deficiency of riboflavin in man is uncommon, because riboflavin is synthesized by the intestinal flora. Riboflavin deficiency usually accompanies other deficiency diseases such as beriberi, pellagra and Kwashiorkor. Nutritional status of riboflavin can be determined by measuring the activation of erythrocyte glutathione reductase by FAD added in vitro.

 

Manifestations: Symptoms are confined to skin and mucous membranes.

 

  1. Glossitis (Greek, glossa = tongue)
  2. Magenta colored tongue
  3. Cheilosis (Greek, cheilos = lip)
  4. Angular stomatitis (inflammation at the corners of mouth)
  5. Circumcorneal vascularization
  6. Proliferation of the bulbar conjunctival capillaries is the earliest sign of riboflavin deficiency.
  7. Personality changes

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B1 (Thiamine): Deficiency causes beriberi, which affects the cardiovascular and nervous systems, but is detected by erythrocyte transketolase activation assay.

 

Option C. Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine): Deficiency can cause peripheral neuropathy and is detected by activation of erythrocyte transaminases.

 

Option D. Vitamin B12 (Cobalamin): Deficiency leads to megaloblastic anemia and neurological symptoms, detected by serum methyl malonate and homocysteine levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin B2 (riboflavin) deficiency, indicated by reduced glutathione reductase activity, can cause symptoms such as a fissured tongue, cheilosis, and peripheral neuropathy.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of infection post-solid organ transplantation in an Indian setting? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cytomegalovirus

 

CMV is most common infection occurring after transplant. Risk depends on induction agent and seropositivity status. Minimal risk for D-/R-(Donor, recipient negative). Highest risk of reactivation in D-/R+ and patients who received anti-lymphocyte therapy. Prophylaxis is given pre-emptively if periodic CMV-DNA PCR are >500 copies/ml with Valgan/ Foscarnet/Cidofovir. Letermovir has no hepato/nephrotoxicity (Safest)

 

D-/R- patients should receive leucodepleted blood products to minimise transmission of CMV

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. EBV infection occurs in 1-2% of post-transplant patients and responds well to acyclovir prophylaxis

 

Option C. VZV reactivation can occur at any point post-transplant

 

Option D. HSV occurs within 1-month post-transplant in the absence of acyclovir prophylaxis Nephrology/infectious diseases/post-transplant

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is the most prevalent and clinically significant viral infection in the post-solid organ transplant setting in India, necessitating targeted prophylaxis and monitoring protocols to mitigate its risks.

 

Reference - Critical Care Nephrology /Chapter 95

questions.text: A patient presents with symptoms of exertional and nocturnal dyspnea, cardiomegaly observed on imaging, pedal edema, a gallop rhythm on cardiac auscultation, and rales in both lungs. Based on this clinical presentation, which suggests congestive heart failure (CHF), which of the following drugs would be most appropriate to prevent the progression of the disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Captopril

 

The patient's clinical presentation is consistent with heart failure, as indicated by symptoms such as dyspnea on exertion, nocturnal dyspnea, cardiomegaly, pedal edema, a gallop rhythm, and rales in the lungs. All the listed drugs can be used in the management of heart failure, but the question specifically asks about preventing the progression of the disease.

 

Captopril is an ACE inhibitor, which has been shown to be effective in reducing mortality and morbidity in patients with heart failure and in preventing the progression of heart failure. It works by decreasing afterload and preload, improving symptoms, and slowing the progression of heart failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Furosemide: Furosemide is a loop diuretic that is used to reduce the symptoms of fluid overload in heart failure, such as pedal edema and pulmonary congestion, but it does not have a significant impact on the progression of the disease.

 

Option B. Digoxin: Digoxin is a cardiac glycoside that can improve symptoms and cardiac function in heart failure but has not been shown to prevent the progression of the disease and is associated with significant toxicity.

 

Option D. Carvedilol: Carvedilol is a beta-blocker that has been shown to improve survival in heart failure. However, it is generally not used as a first-line therapy for acute exacerbation due to its initial negative inotropic effect, but it can be beneficial over the long term for improving cardiac function and reducing the risk of progression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Captopril, an ACE inhibitor, is the best choice for preventing the progression of heart failure due to its effectiveness in reducing mortality and morbidity, decreasing afterload and preload, and improving symptoms and long-term outcomes in heart failure patients.

questions.text: The structure marked with the asterisk in the electron micrograph indicates? (AIIMS 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Secretory vesicles

 

Explanation:

 

Presynaptic secretory vesicles are indicated by the asterisk in the electron micrograph. The structure with the arrowhead represents postsynaptic density.

 

Neurons produce secretory vesicles, which are involved in electrochemical signalling in the brain and neuromuscular junctions.

 

Synapse - electron microscopy

 

 

On electron microscopy:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mitochondria- On an electron microscope, mitochondria appear as round or elliptical bodies 0.5-2.0 micron long, with an outer and inner mitochondrial membrane, cristae, and mitochondrial matrix.

 

 

Option B.  Golgi bodies (or Golgi apparatus) appear as stacks of flattened membranous cisternae surrounded by clusters of vesicles.

 

 

Option D. Ribosomes may be attached to the membrane of the rough endoplasmic reticulum (as shown in the image below), or else, they may exist as monosomes or as a chain of granular structures called polyribosomes associated with mRNA

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Secretory vesicles are essential for neurotransmission at synapses, and play the critical role in neuronal communication.

questions.text: A young woman was found dead at home under mysterious circumstances. Her live-in partner was reported missing. These were the postmortem images taken by the forensic photographer. Which of the following is the likely cause of her death? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Throttling  

 

Manual strangulation, also known as throttling, is a type of asphyxial death where the perpetrator uses his hand to encircle and compress the front and side of the neck

 

In throttling, the following mechanisms may lead to death:

 

Autopsy findings:

 

  • Bruising on the neck

  • Abrasions of the neck

  • Contused tissues of the neck

 

Cause of death in throttling:

 

  • Occlusion of blood supply to the blood to the brain - carotid arteries

  • Occlusion of the airway leading to asphyxia

  • Carotid sinus pressure causing cardiac arrest

 

The given autopsy images are suggestive of throttling.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Strangulation: While strangulation is a general term that includes throttling, the specific mechanism in this case is manual strangulation, which is best described as throttling.

 

Option C. Hanging: Hanging typically presents with a ligature mark around the neck and different positional signs, which are not visible in this image.

 

Option D. Mugging: Mugging involves external pressure applied using limbs or objects, which generally do not produce the distinct bruising and abrasions seen in throttling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Throttling involves manual strangulation by applying pressure to the neck, causing bruises, abrasions, and contusions, and can lead to death by occlusion of blood supply or airway and pressure on the carotid sinus.

questions.text: Which of the following is classified under Biosafety level -3 infections? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) XDR-TB

 

Explanation:

 

XDR-TB (Extensively Drug-Resistant Tuberculosis) requires BSL-3 (Biosafety Level 3) containment due to its high risk of airborne transmission and severe disease potential.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Salmonella: Generally handled under BSL-2 due to lower risk.

 

Option C. Ebola: Handled under BSL-4, given its high risk and lethality.

 

Option D. Congo Crimean Fever: Also requires BSL-4 due to high fatality rates and transmission risk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The classification of pathogens is according to biosafety levels. XDR-TB is managed under BSL-3 conditions due to its airborne risks and drug resistance challenges.

questions.text: Liver produces KB but cannot use KB due to absence of which enzyme:  (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thiophorase

 

The liver lacks the enzyme thiophorase (succinyl-CoA:3-ketoacid CoA transferase) necessary to utilize the ketone bodies it produces. This enzyme is required to convert acetoacetate into acetoacetyl-CoA, which can then be further metabolized into two molecules of acetyl-CoA. Acetyl-CoA is a central molecule in energy metabolism and can enter the citric acid cycle (also known as the Kreb’s cycle) to produce ATP.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thiolase: It is the common enzyme of Ketone body synthesis and KB utilization.

 

Option C. HMG CoA synthase: HMG CoA synthase is RLE of ketone bodies synthesis in the liver. It is an enzyme involved in the synthesis of 3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl-CoA (HMG-CoA), a precursor molecule in the production of cholesterol and ketone bodies. However, the absence of HMG CoA synthase would impact the overall synthesis of ketone bodies rather than their utilization.

 

Option D. HMG CoA reductase: HMG CoA reductase is an enzyme involved in the synthesis of mevalonate, which is a precursor molecule in the production of cholesterol. However, the absence of HMG CoA reductase in the liver would not directly affect the utilization of ketone bodies. It would primarily impact the synthesis of cholesterol and other downstream products.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The liver plays a crucial role in ketone body metabolism. During periods of prolonged fasting or low carbohydrate intake, the liver produces ketone bodies (acetoacetate and β-hydroxybutyrate) through a process called ketogenesis. These ketone bodies are then released into the bloodstream and can be used as an alternative fuel source by various tissues, including the brain, heart, and skeletal muscles.

choices.text: Temperature >38 degree Celsius or <36 degree Celsius

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency room with symptoms of fever, increased respiratory rate, elevated heart rate, and low blood pressure. The physician suspects the patient may have SIRS. Which of the following is not a criteria for SIRS? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Systolic blood pressure <90 mmHg.

 

SIRS is diagnosed when two or more of the following criteria are present: hyperthermia or hypothermia, Tachypnea or low PaCO2, Tachycardia, and abnormal white blood cell count. Systolic blood pressure is not included in the SIRS criteria. Sepsis is defined as SIRS with a documented infection.

 

This is not a criterion for SIRS. SIRS criteria typically include fever or hypothermia, tachycardia (heart rate >90 beats per minute), tachypnea (respiratory rate >20 breaths per minute), and abnormal white blood cell count. Low blood pressure is more related to septic shock, which can be a consequence of severe sepsis but is not one of the primary criteria for SIRS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Temperature >38 degrees Celsius or <36 degrees Celsius: This is a criterion for SIRS.

 

Option C. Respiratory rate >20 bpm: This is a criterion for SIRS. Elevated respiratory rate (>20 breaths per minute) or paCO2 < 32 mm of Hg is one of the criteria used to diagnose SIRS.

 

Option D. Heart rate >90 min: This is a criterion for SIRS. Tachycardia, defined as a heart rate greater than 90 beats per minute, is one of the key criteria for SIRS.

 

In summary, Systolic blood pressure <90 mmHg (option A) is not a criterion for SIRS, while the other options (B, C, and D) are all criteria for SIRS.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child is suffering from selective mutism. He is most probably suffering from? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Childhood anxiety disorder

 

Selective mutism is an anxiety disorder where a child speaks in some settings (like home) but consistently remains silent in others (like school).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Childhood depression: Children with depression might withdraw but don't exhibit selective mutism.

 

Option B. Childhood psychosis: Psychosis presents with hallucinations or delusions, not selective mutism.

 

Option D. Hyperkinetic disorder: ADHD involves inattention or hyperactivity, not selective silence in specific scenarios.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Selective mutism is an anxiety disorder characterized by a child's consistent failure to speak in specific situations, despite being able to speak in others.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 3719.

choices.text: Radial fracture with disruption of triangular fibrocartilage complex and lower radio-ulnar joint
Ulnar fracture with disruption of triangular fibrocartilage complex and lower radio-ulnar joint
