Ulnar shaft fracture and disruption of superior radio-ulnar joint
Radial collateral ligament tear with interosseous membrane tear and radial shaft fracture

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly defines Galeazzi fracture-dislocation?(AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Radial fracture with disruption of triangular fibrocartilage complex and lower radio-ulnar joint

 

GALEAZZI FRACTURE

 

  • The combination of fracture of the distal third of the shaft of the radius and dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint, along with damage to interosseous membrane and Triangular Fibro Cartilage complex, is called Galeazzi Fracture-dislocation.
  • It is the fracture of necessity.
  • A treatment regimen of closed reduction and cast immobilization has a high rate of unsatisfactory results.
  • Open reduction and internal fixation with plate is the treatment of choice in adult.
  • Monteggia and Galeazzi Fractures:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Galeazzi fracture is the fracture of the distal 1/3rd shaft of the radius with disruption of triangular fibrocartilage complex and distal radioulnar joint.

questions.text: Calculate the respiratory quotient (RQ) in a patient with 50kg body weight, if the CO2 exhaled is 200ml/min and 02 consumed is 250 ml/min? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 0.8

 

The respiratory quotient is 0.8.

 

This ratio of carbon dioxide output to oxygen usage is called the respiratory quotient. In the above problem, the CO2 production is 200mL/min, while the 02 consumption is 250mL/min.


So, Respiratory quotient = 200/250 = 0.8

 

Educational Objective:

 

The respiratory quotient (RQ) is used for determining the metabolic utilization of various foods.

 

  • RQ of carbohydrates is 1
  • RQ of fats is 0.70.
  • RQ of proteins is 0.80.

questions.text: Calculate the percentage of burns in a patient that presented to the  emergency with flame burn injury covering the entire  chest and abdomen, the entire right upper limb and full circumference of the  right thigh.(INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 36

 

To calculate the percentage of body surface area affected by burns, the Rule of Nines is often used in adults. This method divides the body into sections that represent 9% (or multiples thereof) of the body surface area.

 

As per the case scenario given :

 

  • Chest and abdomen: 18%
  • Right upper limb: 9%
  • Right thigh: 9%

 

Total = 18% (chest and abdomen) + 9% (right upper limb) + 9% (right thigh) = 36%

 

Educational Objective:

 

This calculation as per the case scenario and Wallace rule of 9 results in a total burned body surface area of 36%, which corresponds to option B.

 

Rule of Nine

choices.text: It has a higher mutation rate than nuclear DNA
It codes for more than 25% of oxidative phosphorylation proteins

questions.text: True regarding Mitochondrial DNA is? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It has a higher mutation rate than nuclear DNA

 

Mitochondrial DNA and RNA

 

  1. There is a dichotomy on the mitochondrial metabolism. Some of the mitochondrial protein synthesis is under the control of mitochondrial DNA; but important proteins of the outer membrane of the mitochondria are synthesized under the influence of nuclear DNA.
  2. The mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) is circular, has about 16,500 nucleotides. The mtDNA has information for synthesis of 2 ribosomal RNAs, 22 tRNAs and 13 proteins. All of them are components of electron transport chain. It has 37 genes that encode 13 protein subunits of the respiratory chain (total of 67 i.e., about 20%). However, most of mitochondrial proteins are encoded by nuclear DNA and synthesized in the cytoplasm.
  3. Maternal inheritance: Since, the mitochondria are inherited cytoplasmically, the mtDNA is inherited from the mother. Mother transmits mtDNA through oocyte.
  4. There are hundreds of copies of mtDNA in each cell (nuclear DNA has only 2 copies).
  5. Heteroplasmy is defined as the presence of normal and mutant mtDNA in different proportions in different cells. During cell division, mtDNA replicates and they segregate to the daughter cells. If a mutation occurs in mtDNA, the daughter cells may inherit the mutant or normal mtDNA.
  6. High mutation rate: 5-10 times that of nuclear DNA
  7. Age-related accumulation of mutations in mtDNA may be responsible for age-related decrease in cellular OXPHOS function, and progression of other degenerative diseases.
  8. Defects in mitochondrial genome will lead to mitochondrial myopathies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. One set from each parent: Incorrect. mtDNA is inherited only from the mother.

 

Option C. It codes for more than 25% of oxidative phosphorylation proteins: Incorrect. mtDNA encodes about 13 protein subunits of the respiratory chain, approximately 20% of the total, not more than 25%.

 

Option D. It has 3 X 10^9 base pairs: Incorrect. mtDNA is much smaller, with about 16,500 base pairs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mitochondrial DNA has a higher mutation rate than nuclear DNA, is maternally inherited, and contains 37 genes encoding essential components of the electron transport chain.

 

Ref - Textbook of Biochemistry for Medical Students 7th edition

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis?  (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vulval cancer

 

Explanation:

 

  • The given image shows a 4 cm × 5 cm irregular fungating lesion present on the left labium majus of the vulva. The most likely diagnosis is vulvar carcinoma.
  • Vulvar cancer is typically characterized by irregular, fungating, or ulcerative lesions on the vulva. These lesions can be painful and may bleed or discharge.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vulval hematoma: Vulval hematomas may occur due to direct trauma or accidental injuries. They present as a localized collection of blood within the vulvar tissues, leading to swelling and bruising, but they do not typically form irregular fungating lesions.

 

Option B. Condyloma acuminata: Condyloma acuminata, also known as genital warts, are commonly caused by HPV types 6 and 11.

 

They appear as multiple, small, cauliflower-like growths and are not typically large, irregular, or fungating.

 

Option D. Bartholin cyst: A Bartholin cyst occurs when the duct of the Bartholin gland gets blocked due to infection, resulting in a buildup of glandular secretions.

 

It presents as a swelling on one side of the vaginal opening, but it is typically smooth and round, not irregular and fungating.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vulvar cancer often presents as an irregular, fungating lesion on the vulva.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg 337,338

questions.text:
Which of the following muscles are supplied by the lateral plantar nerve? (INICET Nov 2023)

 

  1. Abductor hallucis
  2. Flexor digitorum accessorius
  3. Flexor hallucis brevis
  4. First lumbrical
  5. First interossei
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2 and 5

 

 

 

The lateral plantar nerve is a branch of the tibial nerve, which innervates various muscles in the sole of the foot. It divides into superficial and deep branches, each supplying specific muscles.

 

  • Flexor Digitorum Accessorius : This muscle assists in the flexion of the toes and is supplied by the lateral plantar nerve.
  • First Interossei: The interossei muscles, which include the dorsal and plantar interossei, are responsible for abduction and adduction of the toes. The first interossei is supplied by the lateral plantar nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

1. Abductor hallucis: This muscle is supplied by the medial plantar nerve, not the lateral plantar nerve.

 

3. Flexor hallucis brevis: This muscle is also supplied by the medial plantar nerve.

 

4. First lumbrical: The first lumbrical is supplied by the medial plantar nerve, whereas the second, third, and fourth lumbricals are supplied by the lateral plantar nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lateral plantar nerve supplies the flexor digitorum accessorius (quadratus plantae) and the first interossei muscles in the foot.

questions.text: What is the fluid of choice in pediatric patients?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) DNS

 

DNS (Dextrose Normal Saline) is the fluid of choice in pediatric patients. It contains 5% dextrose along with normal saline (0.9% sodium chloride). This combination helps to provide both hydration and glucose, which is essential for energy. Additionally, DNS can help maintain electrolyte balance, which is critical in pediatric patients who are often at risk for dehydration and electrolyte imbalances. In practice, 1 ml of potassium chloride (KCl) is often added to every 100 ml of DNS to ensure adequate potassium levels, which are vital for proper cellular function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. RL (Ringer's Lactate): Ringer's Lactate is often used for fluid resuscitation in adults and in specific conditions such as acidosis. However, it does not contain dextrose, which is necessary for pediatric patients for energy and maintaining blood glucose levels.

 

Option C. NS (Normal Saline): Normal Saline (0.9% sodium chloride) is useful for hydration and electrolyte balance but lacks dextrose. Pediatric patients need a source of glucose, especially in cases of prolonged fasting or illness, making NS alone less suitable than DNS.

 

Option D. 5% dextrose: 5% dextrose provides glucose but lacks the electrolytes found in saline. This can lead to imbalances, particularly in pediatric patients, where maintaining proper electrolyte levels is crucial.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fluid of choice in pediatric patients is DNS (Dextrose Normal Saline), which provides essential hydration, electrolytes, and glucose for energy.

questions.text: Which of the following primary second messengers is involved in the contraction of ciliary muscles while focusing on near objects?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) IP3

 

IP₃ (inositol 1,4,5-triphosphate) is the primary second messenger involved in the contraction of ciliary muscles when focusing on near objects.

 

When focusing on a near object, the parasympathetic nerve fibers are stimulated, leading to the contraction of bilateral ciliary muscles via short ciliary nerves. This contraction relaxes the lens ligaments, thickening the lens and increasing its refractive power to help focus on a near object. This physiological process is known as the accommodation reflex.

 

The contraction of ciliary muscles is mediated through M₃ receptors (muscarinic receptors), and the parasympathetic signaling pathway activates the IP₃-DAG (diacylglycerol) cascade. This leads to the release of intracellular calcium (Ca²⁺), which in turn causes contraction of the ciliary smooth muscle, allowing accommodation.

 

Thus, the contraction of the ciliary muscles during near focusing is driven by IP₃ as the second messenger, via the parasympathetic nervous system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. cAMP: This second messenger typically mediates relaxation, not contraction, of smooth muscles. It works via the β-adrenergic receptors, which would lead to relaxation of ciliary muscles.

 

Option B. cGMP: This messenger is more associated with the nitric oxide pathway and vascular smooth muscle relaxation rather than ciliary muscle contraction.

 

Option C. Na+ inflow through a channel: Sodium ions (Na⁺) do not directly function as a primary second messenger in ciliary muscle contraction. They are involved in generating action potentials but not in the intracellular signaling pathways for muscle contraction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The second messenger inositol 1,4,5-triphosphate (IP₃) plays a crucial role in ciliary muscle contraction during the accommodation reflex, particularly when focusing on near objects. This mechanism involves parasympathetic stimulation of M₃ receptors and the subsequent increase in intracellular calcium.

choices.text: A transverse lie is associated with placenta previa
An external cephalic version can be tried in patients beyond 34 weeks
LSCS is to be done only at the onset of labor

questions.text: A Primigravida presents with a transverse lie at 35 weeks and 0 days of pregnancy. Mark the following statements true regarding this condition.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A transverse lie is associated with placenta previa

 

A transverse lie is associated with placenta previa: True. A transverse lie can often be associated with various factors, one of which is placenta previa. Other contributing factors include:

 

  1. Multiparity (due to a lax abdominal wall and weaker uterine tone).
  2. Prematurity, which affects the center of gravity of the fetus.
  3. The presence of a second twin in multiple gestations.
  4. Hydramnios (excess amniotic fluid).
  5. A contracted pelvis that limits fetal engagement in a longitudinal position.
  6. Pelvic tumors that alter the uterine space.
  7. Congenital uterine malformations, such as arcuate or subseptate uterus.
  8. Intrauterine fetal demise, which may affect the fetus's orientation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Admission is indicated at 35 weeks immediately: False. Admission is generally recommended around 37 weeks for cases of transverse lie, as there is an increased risk of membrane rupture and complications such as cord or hand prolapse. Immediate admission at 35 weeks is typically not required unless other risk factors are present.

 

Option C. An external cephalic version can be tried in patients beyond 34 weeks: False. External cephalic version (ECV) is generally recommended at or after 35 weeks if there are no contraindications. Attempting it too early (such as at 34 weeks) may not be effective, as the fetus could revert to a non-longitudinal position. ECV is contraindicated in cases like placenta previa.

 

Option D. LSCS is to be done only at the onset of labor: False. Elective lower segment cesarean section (LSCS) is the preferred method of delivery in cases of transverse lie with associated risks. If a patient with a transverse lie presents at the onset of labor, an ECV may be attempted if there are no contraindications. If ECV is unsuccessful or contraindicated, immediate LSCS is recommended.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of transverse lie at 36 weeks, transverse lie can be associated with conditions such as placenta previa. Monitoring, admission at 37 weeks, and elective LSCS are recommended to minimize risks associated with labor in this fetal position.

questions.text: Treatment of choice for an acute attack of cluster headache is: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subcutaneous sumatriptan

 

Subcutaneous sumatriptan is shown to be effective in treating acute attacks of cluster headaches. The reference indicates that oral sumatriptan is not effective, whereas subcutaneous sumatriptan has been proven beneficial. Intranasal sumatriptan and intranasal zolmitriptan also are shown to be effective.

 

Additionally, 100% oxygen therapy at a rate of at least 12 liters per minute is effective.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral sumatriptan: Oral sumatriptan has not been shown to be effective in treating acute cluster headache attacks.

 

Option C. 100% oxygen at 6 L/minute: Although 100% oxygen is a treatment option, the effective rate is at least 12 liters per minute, making 6 L/minute inadequate.

 

Option D. 100% oxygen at 8 L/minute: Similar to the previous option, 8 L/minute is below the effective rate of 12 liters per minute required for treating acute cluster headaches.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The treatment of choice for an acute attack of cluster headache is subcutaneous sumatriptan, and 100% oxygen therapy should be administered at a rate of at least 12 liters per minute for effectiveness.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reasons are correct statements, and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion.
Both Assertion and Reasons are correct statements, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion.
The assertion is correct statement, but the Reason is incorrect statement.
The assertion is incorrect statement, but the Reason is correct statement.

questions.text:
Assertion: In pregnancy, anemia has a different cutoff point.


Reason: Physiological hemodilution takes place during pregnancy.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Both Assertion and Reasons are correct statements, and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion.

 

In pregnancy, anemia is assessed differently than in non-pregnant individuals due to the process of physiological hemodilution. Hemodilution occurs as plasma volume increases significantly more than red cell mass, leading to a natural dilution effect on hemoglobin concentration, which can create a lower hemoglobin value. This adjustment is necessary to accommodate the increased blood flow requirements of the fetus and the placenta, making it a critical part of maternal adaptation during pregnancy.

 

The Reason provided, "Physiological hemodilution takes place during pregnancy," is indeed accurate and directly explains why anemia cutoff points differ in pregnant individuals. Physiological hemodilution is essential for supporting fetal development and helps to prevent maternal blood from becoming too viscous, thus promoting better blood flow.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pregnancy, physiological hemodilution necessitates a different cutoff for diagnosing anemia due to the increase in plasma volume relative to red cell mass.

choices.text: rk 39 antigen test, Leishmaniasis
pLDH, Plasmodium malaria
Biopsy, Histoplasmosis
ELISA, HIV

questions.text: A man with FUO has a job that requires traveling around the world. The bone marrow picture is shown below. Which of the following investigation would be the most appropriate in this case? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) rk 39 antigen test, Leishmaniasis

 

This given clinical picture shows A and B. macrophage infested with intracellular Leishmania donovani bodies (arrows) characterized by a kinetoplast and characteristic double dot appearance (Leishman stain) suggestive of Leishmaniasis which can be confirmed by the rk 39 antigen test.

 

There are 3 main forms of leishmaniases: visceral (the most serious form because it is almost always fatal without treatment), cutaneous (the most common, usually causing skin ulcers), and mucocutaneous (affecting mouth, nose and throat).

 

Leishmaniasis is caused by protozoan parasites which are transmitted by the bite of infected female phlebotomine sandflies.

 

Following the discovery of a 39-amino acid residue (k-39) encoded by a kinesin-related gene in the amastigotes of Leishmania chagasi, it has been used in the format of enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA). 

 

Immunochromatographic test (ICT) for detection of antibodies with high sensitivity and specificity.1,4–6 Anti-k39 antibodies are secreted into various body fluids such as urine and sputum along with blood, and have been shown to be useful in the diagnosis of Visceral leishmaniasis (VL). rK39 strip test is rapid and a sensitive and specific indicator of visceral leishmaniasis(VL).

 

Parasitological methods of diagnosis remain the gold standard for diagnosing leishmaniasis. Diagnosis in the laboratory can be achieved by direct examination of amastigotes in giemsa-stained lesion smears of scrapping, biopsies, or impression smears.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. pLDH, Plasmodium malaria: Plasmodium malaria would present differently on a blood smear and would not typically show macrophages with intracellular organisms in a bone marrow sample. The pLDH test is specific for diagnosing malaria, not leishmaniasis.

 

Option C. Biopsy, Histoplasmosis: Histoplasmosis could cause fever of unknown origin and show organisms in macrophages, but the morphology would be different from Leishmania donovani. Histoplasma typically appears as small yeast forms within macrophages, not the double dot appearance seen here.

 

Option D. ELISA, HIV: While HIV can present with fever of unknown origin, it would not directly explain the bone marrow findings of intracellular Leishmania bodies. An ELISA test for HIV is not relevant to diagnosing the cause of the observed bone marrow pathology.

 

Educational Objective

 

The presence of macrophages with intracellular Leishmania donovani bodies in the bone marrow is diagnostic for leishmaniasis. The rk 39 antigen test is a rapid and reliable method for confirming visceral leishmaniasis.

questions.text: The correct order of steps in Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) is: (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Denaturation, Annealing, Extension

 

Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) is a widely used method to amplify specific DNA segments. The process involves three main steps that are repeated in cycles, resulting in the exponential amplification of the target DNA sequence.

 

Steps of PCR:

 

 

The steps of 1, 2 and 3 are repeated results in the exponential amplification of DNA segments of defined length. In each cycle, the DNA strands are doubled. Thus 20 cycles provide for 1 million times amplifications. These cycles are generally repeated by automated instrument, called Thermal cycler.

 

After the amplification procedure, DNA hybridization technique or Southern blot analysis with a suitable probe, shows the presence of the DNA in the sample tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct order of steps in Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) is Denaturation, Annealing, and Extension. These steps are repeated in cycles to exponentially amplify the target DNA segment.

questions.text: Match the following cranial nerves with their respective functions: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 1-B, 2-A, 3-C, 4-D
 

Explanation:

 

  1. Facial nerve - B. Taste from anterior two-thirds of the tongue: The facial nerve (CN VII) is responsible for carrying taste sensations from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. It also controls the muscles of facial expression.
  2. Spinal accessory nerve - A. Shrugging of the shoulder: The spinal accessory nerve (CN XI) innervates the trapezius muscle, which is responsible for actions such as shrugging the shoulder and scapula elevation. It also contributes to head rotation.
  3. Glossopharyngeal nerve - C. Taste from the posterior one-third of the tongue: The glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) carries taste sensations from the posterior one-third of the tongue. It also plays a role in swallowing and provides sensory information from the throat and tonsils.
  4. Mandibular nerve - D. Chewing: The mandibular nerve (V3) is a branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V) and is responsible for innervating the muscles of mastication (chewing), as well as providing sensory input to the lower jaw, teeth, and gums.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: It is the body's response to anything that requires attention or action causing physical, emotional, or psychological strain

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate definition of stress? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is the body's response to anything that requires attention or action causing physical, emotional, or psychological strain.

 

Stress is a broad term that encompasses the body's physical, emotional, and psychological responses to any demand or threat, whether real or perceived.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. External stress: It is inaccurate as not all stress arises from external pressure. Personal thoughts, emotions, and internal conflicts can also induce stress.

 

Option B. Muscle tension: It simplifies stress to just "mental tension." While mental tension can be a component of stress, the definition doesn't capture the breadth of physiological and psychological reactions associated with stress.

 

Option D. Internal strain: It refers to the outcome of the stress rather than the cause or process of stress itself.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Stress can be conceptualized as the body's adaptive response to demands or threats. It's not just a psychological phenomenon; it has physiological correlates as well. Stressors can be external (e.g., environmental pressures) or internal (e.g., illness, or undergoing a medical procedure), and they can be short-lived (acute) or long-term (chronic).

 

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 2117

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are independently false statements.
The assertion is independently a true statement, but the reason is independently a false statement.
Both assertion and reason are independently true statements, but the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion.
Both assertion and reason are independently true statements, and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion.

questions.text:
Choose the most appropriate answer: (INICET NOV 2022)

 

Assertion: In phenylketonuria, the urine has a mousy odor.

 

Reason: The serum levels of tyrosine, dopamine, and norepinephrine are decreased in phenylketonuria.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both assertion and reason are independently true statements, but the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion.

 

  • Assertion: The statement that "In phenylketonuria, the urine has a mousy odor" is true. The mousy or musty odor of the urine in phenylketonuria (PKU) is due to the accumulation of phenylacetate, one of the metabolites of phenylalanine.
  • Reason: The statement that "The serum levels of tyrosine, dopamine, and norepinephrine are decreased in phenylketonuria" is also true. Phenylketonuria is characterized by a deficiency of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase, which converts phenylalanine to tyrosine. Consequently, low levels of tyrosine lead to reduced synthesis of catecholamines such as dopamine, norepinephrine, and epinephrine.

 

However, the reason provided is not the correct explanation for the assertion. The mousy odor in PKU is directly related to the accumulation of phenylacetate, not to the decreased levels of tyrosine or catecholamines.

 

Detailed Mechanism:

 

  • Phenylketonuria (PKU): PKU is an inborn error of metabolism caused by a deficiency of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase or, less commonly, a defect in enzymes responsible for producing tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4). This defect results in impaired conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine, leading to the accumulation of phenylalanine and its metabolites, such as phenylpyruvate and phenylacetate, which are excreted in the urine.
  • Tyrosine and Catecholamine Synthesis: Tyrosine is a precursor for the synthesis of catecholamines, including dopamine, norepinephrine, and epinephrine. In PKU, the deficiency of tyrosine leads to reduced synthesis of these neurotransmitters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In phenylketonuria, the mousy odor of urine is due to the accumulation of phenylacetate, while decreased levels of tyrosine and catecholamines are a result of the impaired conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine. However, the two phenomena are not causally related.

choices.text: Initiate targeted temperature management of <33°C, if the patient is confused
Perform emergent cardiac intervention if ST elevation is present in the ECG
Maintain a mean arterial pressure (MAP) above 65 mmHg

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the management of patients who have achieved return of spontaneous circulation following CPR? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Initiate targeted temperature management of <33°C, if the patient is confused

 

In post-resuscitation care after return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC), targeted temperature management (TTM) should be maintained between 33–36°C, not below 33°C. Lower temperatures increase the risk of coagulopathy, bleeding, and infections like pneumonia. For patients with high bleeding risk or coagulopathy, the target should be 36–37.5°C.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Target SpO₂ >94%: Initially, target SpO₂ should be >92%, and once intubated and on mechanical ventilation, the target should be >94%. Overall target range is 92–98%.

 

Option C. Perform emergent cardiac intervention if ST elevation is present in the ECG: If STEMI is identified as the cause of cardiac arrest, immediate cardiac catheterization should be performed within 2 hours as it's a reversible cause.

 

Option D. Maintain a mean arterial pressure (MAP) above 65 mmHg: This is the minimum MAP that should be achieved using vasopressors and IV fluids. The ideal MAP range is 80–100 mmHg.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In post-resuscitation care after ROSC, targeted temperature management should be maintained between 33–36°C, with higher targets (36–37.5°C) for patients at risk of bleeding or coagulopathy. Temperature should never be targeted below 33°C due to increased complications.

choices.text: Wait and watch for 4 weeks
Repeat TVS after one week
Serum HCG levels

questions.text: A lady with 7 weeks amenorrhea presented with slight vaginal spotting. Crown Rump Length was 5 mm with a well-formed gestational sac with a calculated gestational age of 5.6 weeks on TVS. What is the next line of management? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Repeat TVS after one week

 

In the case described, the patient has a gestational sac and a crown-rump length (CRL) of 5 mm, with a calculated gestational age of 5.6 weeks based on transvaginal sonography (TVS). The guidelines for assessing early pregnancy viability are:

 

  • Absence of an embryo at a mean sac diameter (MSD) ≥ 25 mm indicates an anembryonic pregnancy.
  • Absence of cardiac activity at a CRL ≥ 7 mm indicates a non-viable pregnancy.

 

In this scenario, the CRL is 5 mm, which is below the threshold where the absence of cardiac activity would indicate a non-viable pregnancy (≥ 7 mm). There is no mention of cardiac activity in the current ultrasound findings, so it is crucial to monitor the pregnancy further before making any conclusions.

 

The best course of action is to repeat the transvaginal ultrasound after one week to check for the presence of cardiac activity and further development of the embryo. This approach allows for a more accurate assessment of the viability of the pregnancy.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Wait and watch for 4 weeks: Waiting for 4 weeks without further evaluation could delay necessary medical intervention and is not recommended for timely assessment of pregnancy viability.

 

Option C. Serum HCG levels: While measuring serum HCG levels can provide some information about the progression of the pregnancy, it is less specific than ultrasound for determining viability, particularly in the context of assessing cardiac activity.

 

Option D. Medical intervention: Immediate medical intervention is not warranted at this stage without further evidence. The repeat ultrasound will provide more clarity on whether intervention is needed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In early pregnancy with a CRL of less than 7 mm and no documented cardiac activity, the best approach is to repeat the transvaginal ultrasound after one week to reassess for the presence of cardiac activity and viability of the pregnancy.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg 645

questions.text: A farmer from the sub-Himalayan belt had a thorn prick injury a year back and developed a warty, verrucous growth at the site of prick. A skin biopsy sample was taken and sent for histopathological examination. The characteristic microscopic body as shown in the image was seen. Which of the following could be the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chromoblastomycosis

 

The history of a slowly spreading warty, verrucous lesion following a thorn prick injury and the histopathological image showing medlar bodies is suggestive of chromoblastomycosis.

 

It is a chronic deep cutaneous fungal infection usually affecting the limbs at the inoculation site

 

Causative agents include several fungi found in soil, wood and decaying plant material:

 

  • Phialophora verrucosa
  • Fonsecaea pedrosi (most common pathogen, accounts for > 90% of the cases in South America)
  • Fonsecaea compacta
  • Cladosporium carrionii
  • Rhinocladiella aquaspersa (Ramichloridium cerophilum)

 

Common clinical presentation is verrucous lesion over extremities of adult men engaged in outdoor work. Lesion starts as a small firm red / gray bump on the traumatized skin on the foot or hand. Grows slowly (2 mm/year) to form raised hyperkeratotic (crusted, warty-looking) plaque

 

Histologically, the lesions are granulomatous and the dark sclerotic bodies may be seen within leukocytes or giant cells called medlar/copper penny bodies.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blastomycosis: This is a fungal infection caused by Blastomyces dermatitidis. It typically presents with flu-like symptoms, skin lesions, and sometimes lung involvement. The histopathology would show broad-based budding yeast rather than medlar bodies.

 

Option B. Pheohyphomycosis: This refers to a group of fungal infections caused by dematiaceous (dark-walled) fungi. The infection can present in various forms, from superficial to deep infections, but it does not typically produce medlar bodies.

 

Option D. Sporotrichosis: Caused by Sporothrix schenckii, this infection usually follows a thorn prick and presents as nodular lesions that can ulcerate. The characteristic histopathological finding is cigar-shaped yeast, not medlar bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chromoblastomycosis is characterized by a slowly spreading warty, verrucous lesion following a thorn prick injury, with histopathological evidence of medlar bodies.

choices.text: Clean cut incised wound

questions.text: A man was brought to the emergency department after he was attacked by his lover’s husband with an axe. On examination, crushing of the hair bull was seen. Identify the type of wound? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Lacerated wound  

 

  • The type of wound in which the crushing of the hair bulb is seen is a lacerated wound.
  • Laceration- A laceration is a wound that is produced by the tearing of soft body tissue. This type of wound is often irregular and jagged
  • It is produced by blunt weapons or heavy relatively sharp-edged weapons such as axe.
  • In scalp lacerations hair bulbs, nerves, and vessels, are irregularly torn and crushed

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Clean cut incised wound: Typically has clean, sharp edges caused by sharp instruments like knives or razors.
  • Option C. Chop wound: While an axe can cause a chop wound, the presence of crushed hair bulbs suggests more of a laceration pattern.
  • Option D. Avulsion injury: Involves the skin and underlying tissues being forcibly detached from the body.

 

Educational objective

 

Classification of a Laceration:

 

  • Split laceration (incised-like laceration): When the skin is crushed between two hard objects.
  • Incised-looking lacerated wound It is seen where the skin overlies an area of the bone where there is scanty underlying subcutaneous tissue such as the scalp, forehead, shin.
  • Avulsed laceration: A lesion where the skin separates or peels off by tearing from the underlying tissues.
  • Tears: Tearing of skin and subcutaneous tissue from localized impact
  • Stretch laceration: It occurs due to the over-stretching of the skin, beyond its elasticity.
  • Cut laceration: Injury by a heavy sharp-edged instrument like axe.

questions.text:
Which of the following muscles receive innervation from the Superior Gluteal Nerve?  (INICET MAY 2023)

 

1. Gluteus Medius

2. Gluteus Minimus

3. Tensor fascia lata

4. Piriformis
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1, 2, 3

 

Superior Gluteal Nerve (L4, L5, S1) supplies to Gluteus Medius, Minimus and Tensor Fascia Lata (damage leads to positive Trendelenburg sign). Accompanied by the superior gluteal vessels, the nerve leaves the pelvis via the greater sciatic foramen above piriformis, and divides into superior and inferior branches. The superior branch accompanies the upper branch of the deep division of the superior gluteal artery to supply gluteus medius and occasionally gluteus minimus. The inferior branch runs with the lower ramus of the deep division of the superior gluteal artery across gluteus minimus, supplies the glutei medius and minimus and ends in tensor fasciae latae.

 

Piriformis is supplied by the nerve to the piriformis (S1, S2).

 

 

1. Gluteus Medius: True. The gluteus medius muscle receives innervation from the superior gluteal nerve. This nerve supplies motor neurons to the gluteus medius and plays a crucial role in the abduction and stabilization of the hip joint.
 

2. Gluteus Minimus: True. Similar to the gluteus medius, the gluteus minimus muscle is also innervated by the superior gluteal nerve. It functions in hip abduction and stabilization.
 

3. Tensor Fascia Lata (TFL): True. The tensor fascia lata muscle, often referred to as the TFL, receives innervation from the superior gluteal nerve. This muscle assists in various movements, including flexion, abduction, and medial rotation of the hip.

 

Other Option

 

4. Piriformis: False. The piriformis muscle is not innervated by the superior gluteal nerve. Instead, it is primarily innervated by the nerve to the piriformis, which arises from the sacral plexus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gluteus Medius, Gluteus Minimus, and Tensor Fascia Lata receive innervation from the Superior Gluteal Nerve (L4, L5, and S1 nerve roots). Piriformis, on the other hand, is innervated by one of the branch of sacral plexus.

choices.text: Delayed clamping, cutting and ligation of cord

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the active management of the third stage of labor to prevent post-partum hemorrhage? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gentle massage of uterus

 

AMTSL

 

Purpose: To prevent postpartum hemorrhage (PPH), a major cause of maternal death.

 

  1. Give a uterotonic drug
    • Oxytocin 10 IU IM immediately after the birth of the baby
    • This helps the uterus contract and reduce bleeding
  2. Controlled Cord Traction (CCT)
    • Gently pull the umbilical cord while supporting the uterus to help deliver the placenta
    • Only if trained and placenta is ready to come
  3. Intermittent uterine tone assessment

 

Delayed cord clamping

 

  • Wait 1–3 minutes before clamping the umbilical cord
  • Improves baby’s iron stores and reduces anemia

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uterotonic within 1 minute of delivery: This is a critical step in AMTSL to prevent PPH by promoting uterine contractions.

 

Option B. Delayed clamping, cutting and ligation of cord: Delayed cord clamping (after 1 to 3 minutes) is recommended for all births to enhance neonatal outcomes

 

Option D. Controlled cord traction: This is a part of AMTSL to aid in the delivery of the placenta.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The active management of the third stage of labor includes the administration of a uterotonic, controlled cord traction, and assessing uterine tone rather than sustained uterine massage for all women who have received a uterotonic.

 

Ref: https://iris.who.int/bitstream/handle/10665/120082/WHO_RHR_14.20_eng.pdf?sequence=1

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with an ulcerative lesion noted near the nose/medical canthus. What is the probable diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Basal cell carcinoma 

 

  • The patient's presentation with an ulcerative lesion near the nose/medial canthus with rolled out edges is a basal cell carcinoma. 

 

This is the most common type of skin cancer, often appearing in sun-exposed areas such as the face. BCC frequently presents as a pearly bump with telangiectatic vessels or as a flat, flesh-colored or brown scar-like lesion. Ulceration is common in neglected or advanced BCC, particularly near critical areas like the nose and eyes, where it can cause significant local destruction. Given its common presentation and the description provided, BCC is a very likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lentigo Maligna Melanoma: This is a type of melanoma that typically occurs on sun-exposed areas of the skin, particularly the face and the arms, in older adults. It begins as a patch that darkens, enlarges, and sometimes becomes nodular, indicating progression to melanoma. It's less common for lentigo maligna to present initially as an ulcerative lesion, making this a less likely diagnosis.

 

Option C. Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC): SCC is a type of skin cancer that can also appear on sun-exposed skin and may develop from a pre-existing actinic keratosis. It can be more aggressive than BCC and typically presents as a thick, rough, scaly patch that can bleed if bumped. It can ulcerate but often has a more rapid growth compared to BCC.

 

Option D. Nevus: A nevus is a common skin growth (mole), which can be present from birth or appear during childhood or young adulthood. While most nevi are benign, changes in their appearance, such as ulceration, require evaluation to rule out malignant transformation, such as into melanoma.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Given the description of an ulcerative lesion near critical areas like the nose and medial canthus, Basal Cell Carcinoma is the most probable diagnosis due to its frequent occurrence in these regions and its tendency to ulcerate. Treatment typically involves surgical excision, and in some cases, topical or systemic therapy may be considered.

choices.text: Crystal violet, iodine, acid alcohol, carbol fuchsin
Methanol, Kinyoun's carbol fuchsin, acid alcohol, methylene blue
Methanol, dilute carbol fuchsin, acid alcohol, crystal violet
Methylene blue, iodine, acid alcohol, carbol fuchsin

questions.text: A HIV patient with fever, chronic diarrhea presented to OPD. His stool was examined which showed the following oocysts. Identify the components used for staining the stool? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Methanol, Kinyoun's carbol fuchsin, acid alcohol, methylene blue

 

Diarrhea in an HIV patient is suggestive of a coccidian parasitic infestation. The image shows a blue background and red-stained oocysts, suggestive of modified acid-fast stain positive Cryptosporidium parvum.

 

The Modified Ziehl-Neelsen stain (mZN stain) is a type of differential bacteriological stain used to identify acid-fast organisms, mainly Mycobacteria. Acid fast organisms are those which are capable of retaining the primary stain when treated with an acid fast (holding capacity).

 

Members of the Actinomycetes, genus Nocardia (N. brasiliensis and N. asteroides are opportunistic pathogens) are partially acid-fast. Oocysts of coccidian parasites, such as Cryptosporidium and Isospora, are also acid-fast. Hence, they can also be detected and identified through mZN staining procedure.

 

The reagents used for modified Ziehl–Neelsen staining are absolute methanol (for fixation), kinyoun’s carbol fuchsin (primary stain), acid alcohol (for decolorization), and methylene blue (counter stain).

 

Unlike the ZN-stain, the modified ZN stain does not require heating of the reagents. Kinyoun’s carbol fuschin has greater concentration of phenol and basic fuschin and does not require heating to stain properly. Heat is used as mordant (A mordant is a substance that increases the affinity of the cell wall for a stain by binding to the primary stain, thus forming an insoluble complex, which gets trapped in the cell wall). Acid-fast bacilli are bright red after staining.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Crystal violet, iodine, acid alcohol, carbol fuchsin: This combination is not used for modified acid-fast staining but is related to Gram staining.

 

Option C. Methanol, dilute carbol fuchsin, acid alcohol, crystal violet: This is incorrect as the proper primary stain for the modified Ziehl-Neelsen stain is Kinyoun’s carbol fuchsin.

 

Option D. Methylene blue, iodine, acid alcohol, carbol fuchsin: This combination is incorrect for modified Ziehl-Neelsen staining.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The modified Ziehl-Neelsen stain uses methanol for fixation, Kinyoun’s carbol fuchsin as the primary stain, acid alcohol for decolorization, and methylene blue as the counterstain to detect acid-fast organisms like Cryptosporidium parvum.

questions.text: A patient presented with severe watery diarrhea resembling that of rice gruel stool. Damage of which structure is likely to have resulted in the above finding? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Zona Occludens

 

  • The structure that is most likely damaged to result in severe watery diarrhea resembling rice gruel stool is the Zona Occludens.
  • Zona Occludens, also known as Tight Junctions, are specialized intercellular junctions between epithelial cells that regulate the movement of substances across the intestinal wall. They are located at the apical end of the lateral membrane of adjacent epithelial cells and are responsible for maintaining the integrity and impermeability of the intestinal barrier.
  • Damage to the Zona Occludens can result in increased permeability of the intestinal barrier, leading to the leakage of water and electrolytes into the intestinal lumen, resulting in watery diarrhea. This type of diarrhea is often seen in infectious diarrhea caused by bacterial or viral pathogens that can damage the tight junctions, leading to increased intestinal permeability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gap Junction: Incorrect. Gap junctions are involved in cell-cell communication and the passage of ions and small molecules between adjacent cells, but they are not directly involved in regulating intestinal permeability.

 

Option C. Adherent Junction: Incorrect. Adherent junctions are involved in maintaining cell-cell adhesion but are not primarily responsible for regulating intestinal permeability.

 

Option D. Hemidesmosomes: Incorrect. Hemidesmosomes are involved in cell-matrix adhesion and do not play a role in the regulation of intestinal permeability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Damage to the Zona Occludens (Tight Junctions) can result in increased intestinal permeability, leading to severe watery diarrhea. These tight junctions are crucial for maintaining the integrity of the intestinal barrier.

questions.text: All of the following ions have decreased concentration on the luminal side of proximal convoluted tubule except: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chloride

 

The concentration of chloride on the luminal side is more when compared to sodium, glucose, and amino acids.

 

In the first half of the proximal tubule, sodium is reabsorbed by co-transport along with glucose, amino acids, and other solutes thus decreasing their concentrations markedly along the length of the proximal tubule. Thus, the solution will have a higher concentration of chloride which is around 105 mEg/L.

 

In the second half of the proximal tubule, sodium gets re-absorbed along with chloride. Higher chloride (approx. 140meq/L) concentration favors its own diffusion from the lumen into the renal interstitial fluid.

 

Proximal tubule’s high permeability to water, increases water reabsorption thus helps in maintaining sodium concentration and total osmolarity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amino acids: Their concentration decreases significantly due to nearly complete reabsorption.

 

Option B. Glucose: Similarly, glucose concentration decreases significantly because of active reabsorption.

 

Option D. Bicarbonate: Its concentration also decreases due to active reabsorption facilitated by carbonic anhydrase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chloride concentration on the luminal side of the proximal convoluted tubule does not decrease as significantly as amino acids, glucose, and bicarbonate due to the preferential reabsorption of these other solutes in the early segments of the PCT.

questions.text: Which of the following vessels will serve as an alternate source of blood supply to prevent uterine ischemia, in case the primary artery is ligated in the event of PPH?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ovarian artery


In the event of postpartum hemorrhage (PPH), bleeding typically arises from the uterine artery, which may need to be ligated to control hemorrhage. When the uterine artery is ligated, the ovarian artery can serve as an alternate source of blood supply to the uterus, helping to prevent ischemia. This is because the ovarian artery, which is a direct branch of the abdominal aorta, has an anastomotic connection with the uterine artery. This connection allows the ovarian artery to compensate for the decreased blood flow when the uterine artery is compromised.

 

The order of ligation of vessels in cases of atonic PPH to manage bleeding generally follows:

 

  1. Uterine artery ligation
  2. Ovarian artery ligation if needed
  3. Internal iliac artery ligation as a more drastic measure

 

This anatomical relationship is crucial in managing severe bleeding during PPH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Uterine artery: This is the primary vessel supplying blood to the uterus. In the event of severe PPH, the uterine artery is typically the vessel that is ligated to control bleeding. Hence, it cannot act as an alternate source of blood flow when it is the vessel being ligated.

 

Option C. Arcuate artery: The arcuate arteries are branches of the uterine artery, which supply the myometrium. Since they are distal branches of the uterine artery, they do not serve as an alternative blood supply if the main uterine artery is ligated.

 

Option D. Round ligament artery: The artery to the round ligament is a branch of the ovarian artery, but it does not provide a significant alternative blood flow to the uterus in the context of uterine artery ligation. Its role in uterine perfusion is minimal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of postpartum hemorrhage where the uterine artery is ligated, the ovarian artery can serve as an alternate source of blood flow to prevent uterine ischemia due to its anastomotic connection with the uterine artery. Understanding the vascular anatomy is critical for managing severe PPH effectively.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man was brought to the emergency department in an unconscious state. He had a fever for the past two days and is a known case of severe COPD. His ECG is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Multifocal atrial tachycardia

 

Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) is a type of supraventricular tachycardia that occurs due to multiple abnormal electrical foci within the atria. It is characterized by the presence of at least three different P-wave morphologies on an ECG, as seen in this case. This condition often arises in patients with chronic pulmonary diseases, such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), especially during an acute illness like a fever or infection. The patient’s history of severe COPD and the ECG findings of varying P-wave morphologies are consistent with MAT.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ventricular tachycardia: This condition presents with broad, wide QRS complexes and regular rhythm, which is not consistent with the ECG findings in this case.

 

Option C. Atrial fibrillation: Atrial fibrillation is another type of supraventricular tachycardia, but it is characterized by the absence of distinct P waves and irregular RR intervals. In this case, distinct P waves of different morphologies are present, ruling out atrial fibrillation.

 

Option D. Atrial tachycardia: Atrial tachycardia is a type of supraventricular tachycardia but typically arises from a single focus, leading to uniform P-wave morphologies. This is not consistent with the presence of multiple P-wave morphologies seen in MAT.

 

Educational Objective:


Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) is commonly seen in patients with chronic pulmonary diseases and is characterized by irregular RR intervals and at least three distinct P-wave morphologies on an ECG. Recognizing these ECG features is essential for accurate diagnosis.

choices.text: Risk of bladder injury in case of PAS
Risk of bowel injury in case of PAS

questions.text: A 39-year-old G6P2L1A3 presents with a history of previous 2 LSCS with PAS. What will you NOT counsel her about? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Risk of bowel injury in case of PAS

 

Explanation:

 

In cases of placenta accreta spectrum (PAS), the main risks include bleeding requiring transfusion, bladder injury, and possibly peripartum hysterectomy. Bowel injury is less commonly associated with PAS unless extreme or exceptional surgical complications occur.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Need for blood transfusion: It is common to counsel about the need for blood transfusion due to the high risk of hemorrhage.

 

Option B. Risk of bladder injury in case of PAS: Bladder injury is a significant risk if the placenta invades the bladder area.

 

Option D. Risk of peripartum hysterectomy: Peripartum hysterectomy may be necessary if the placenta is inseparable from the uterus.

 

Educational objective:

 

When counseling a patient with a history of previous cesarean sections and PAS, focus on the more likely complications such as significant bleeding, bladder injury, and the possibility of needing a hysterectomy, rather than bowel injury.
